<main class="wp-block-group site-content is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
	<div class="entry-content wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained">
<div class="alignfull has-wide-width wp-block-whitehouse-topper">
	<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__inner-container">
		<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__content">
			
							<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__eyebrow">
					<a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/remarks/">Remarks<svg class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__eyebrow--icon" width="11" height="11" viewBox="0 0 11 11" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
<path d="M0.724808 1.45055C0.732563 0.940756 1.15149 0.539597 1.66097 0.554084L8.18243 0.73743C8.43709 0.74459 8.66622 0.854307 8.83047 1.02583C8.99471 1.19735 9.09441 1.43101 9.09053 1.68575C9.08278 2.19554 8.66385 2.5967 8.15436 2.58221L3.85933 2.46146L10.0157 8.89043C10.3703 9.2608 10.3618 9.84465 9.99583 10.1951C9.62987 10.5455 9.04621 10.5288 8.69154 10.1584L2.5352 3.72945L2.46984 8.02568C2.46209 8.53547 2.04316 8.93663 1.53368 8.92214C1.02419 8.90766 0.617659 8.48345 0.625575 7.97383L0.724808 1.45055Z" fill="currentColor" />
</svg>
</a>				</div>
			
							<h1 class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__headline">
					PRESS BRIEFING BY PRESS SECRETARY KAROLINE LEAVITT, DEPUTY CHIEF OF STAFF STEPHEN MILLER, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR KEVIN HASSETT, AND NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR MIKE WALTZ				</h1>
			
			
				<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta">
					<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta--byline-subcategory">
						
<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-byline-subcategory">
	The White House</div>
					</div>
					
					<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta--date">
						<div class="wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2025-02-20T20:00:16-05:00">February 20, 2025</time></div>					</div>
				</div>

			
					</div>
	</div>
</div>



<p class="has-text-align-left"><br>1:05 P.M. EST<br><br> MS. LEAVITT: Hello. Good afternoon, everybody. I brought some heavy hitters in here with me today.<br><br>Today marks one month of President Trump&#8217;s return to the Oval Office, and there is no denying this administration is off to a historic start. The President has already signed 73 executive orders. That is more than double the number signed by Joe Biden and more than quadruple the number signed by Barack Obama over the same period.<br><br>These executive orders have ended burdensome regulations; sealed the border; unleashed our domestic energy sector; eliminated divisive DEI from our federal government; stopped the weaponization of government; cut waste, fraud, and abuse; reinstituted America First trade and foreign policies; and ultimately restored common sense.<br><br>The President also signed the Laken Riley Act into law, which ensures ICE will detain illegal aliens arrested or charged with theft or violence.<br><br>As of today, the Senate has already confirmed 18 Cabinet-level nominees, which is more than at this point under the Obama administration in 2009 and more than double the pace of the Biden administration in 2021.<br><br>And today, we expect Kash Patel to be confirmed as the next director of the FBI.<br><br>We are proud to announce that the president will host his first official Cabinet meeting here at the White House next Wednesday, February 26th.<br><br>In just four weeks, President Trump has already hosted the leaders of Israel, Japan, Jordan, and India. And next Monday, the President will host France&#8217;s President, Emmanuel Macron, and on Thursday, the UK Prime Minister, Keir Starmer, will visit the White House as well.<br><br>As you all know, over the past month, the President has taken questions from the press &#8212; all of you &#8212; nearly every single day, sometimes on multiple different occasions in the same day, on any topic any of you wish to talk about.<br><br>President Trump set the tone on this approach immediately when he took more than 12 times the questions in his first few hours in office as Joe Biden did in his entire first week.<br><br>Yesterday, we hosted a local media row here at the White House with television and radio stations from across the country that reached up to 60 million viewers and listeners.<br><br>In our ongoing pursuit of transparency, on this one-month celebration, I am thrilled to bring three of my colleagues and our policy experts here at the White House to further recap this incredible first month of accomplishments in greater detail.<br><br>We have Deputy Chief of Staff for Policy and Homeland Security Advisor Stephen Miller; the Director of the National Economic Council, Kevin Hassett; and our National Security Advisor, Mike Waltz.<br><br>I will hand it over to them. They will deliver brief remarks on the accomplishments of this administration in the first month, and then we will open it up to Q and A. When we open up the Q and A portion, I do ask, for the sake of efficiency in this room, that you direct your question to the principal you seek an answer from. And I will call on you in this room.<br><br>But first I will let them roll through their remarks. And first up, I&#8217;ll turn it over to Stephen Miller.<br><br>MR. MILLER: Thank you. It&#8217;s great to be back.<br><br>And I want to just thank you all for joining today our one-month celebration of the most historic opening to a presidency in American history. No president comes close to what Donald Trump has achieved over just the last 30 days.<br><br>He has packed eight years of transformative action restoring this nation, restoring our laws, restoring fairness, restoring economic opportunity, restoring national security in just one month. No one in this country has ever seen anything like it.<br><br>And when you look at the consequentiality and the significance and the transformative nature of the actions he&#8217;s taking, it truly defies description. For example, in just one area, this nation has been plagued and crippled by illegal discrimination: diversity, equity, and inclusion policies. It strangled our economy. It has undermined public safety. It has made every aspect of life more difficult, more painful, and less safe.<br><br>He has ended all DEI across the federal government. He has terminated all federal workers involved in promulgating these unlawful policies. He has ended diversity, equity, and inclusion in all federal contracting. He has restored merit as the cornerstone of all federal policy; restored the full, fair, impartial enforcement of our federal civil rights laws for the first time in generations; and he has cracked down on individuals across this government and nonprofits who have engaged in illegal racial discrimination against the American people.<br><br>This includes making clear to every educational institution in this country that ending diversity, equity, and inclusion, ending unlawful race discrimination is a precondition of receiving federal funds.<br><br>He has also saved women&#8217;s sports by ending the participation of men in women&#8217;s sports. He has ended radical gender ideology across the entire federal government, and he&#8217;s pressured the private sector to also end and combat radical gender ideology. He&#8217;s reestablished the scientific and biological truth that there are only two sexes in this country &#8212; male and female &#8212; that those are biologically based determinations. They are not based and can never be based on gender identity.<br><br>That includes rooting out of the Department of Defense all DEI policies, all critical race theory, all gender madness, and once again having a military that is focused solely and exclusively on readiness, preparedness, and lethality.<br><br>As I&#8217;m sure Kevin will talk about more, of course, he has undertaken a historic cost-cutting effort across the federal government, launching the first-ever Department of Government Efficiency, uncovering corruption on a scale that we never thought imaginable, terminating every single federal worker that we &#8212; that we have found to be engaged in the corruption and theft and the waste of taxpayer dollars, and already saving $50 billion in a single year, which over a 10-year period would be $500 billion. Just think about how vast and enormous that sum is.<br><br>Of course, as you all know, he has renamed the Gulf of Mexico to its correct and proper name: the Gulf of America. He has renamed Mount Denali into Mount McKinley, part of a historic effort to restore patriotism and national pride all across this land.<br><br>He has ended the weaponization of the federal government, restored the Department of Justice to its true mission of combating threats to this nation and keeping the American people safe.<br><br>He has ended all federal censorship of free speech. This has been one of the greatest crises that has plagued this nation. Years and years and years, the federal government violating the First Amendment to take away Americans right of free speech &#8212; President Trump has ended that. And he has demanded that all federal workers, all law enforcement cease any effort to intimidate the rights of Americans or to police their speech.<br><br>He has also restored the death penalty at the Department of Justice, including for illegal aliens who commit murder, including for those who murder cops, and including for all of those who threaten Americans with heinous acts of violence. The death penalty is back. Law and order is back. The streets are being made safe once again.<br><br>On the public health front, he has launched the nation&#8217;s first-ever commission &#8212; the MAHA Commission &#8212; Make America Healthy Again, following the historic confirmation of RFK Jr., to finally uncover the true root causes of the public health crisis in this country, the childhood disease epidemic in this country, the spiraling rates of pediatric cancer and devastating childhood sickness.<br><br>He has finally created a situation where the federal heal- &#8212; health agencies in this country will be focused on preventing disease, on keeping children from getting sick in the first place, not sentencing them to a lifetime in and out of hospitals, suffering needlessly, when we can find ways to prevent this epidemic of illness.<br><br>Then, of course, on homeland security. Today, it is officially the law of the land at the conclusion of the congressional notification process that six Mexican cartels and two transnational gangs &#8212; Tren de Aragua, or TDA, and MS-13 &#8212; so eight organizations in total &#8212; are now formally designated as foreign terrorist organizations, which means that every single member of those organizations who operates on U.S. soil is now, as a legal matter, a terrorist, and they will be treated as terrorists.<br><br>This is a sea change in U.S. policy. And this means the Department of Justice and the Department of Homeland Security, along with the rest of U.S. law enforcement and the Department of Defense, are now operating in a legal reality where these cartels are recognized as terrorists, and there will be a whole-of-government effort to remove these terrorists from our soil and to degrade their ability to threaten or undermine any American security or sovereignty interests.<br><br>Border crossings since the day he took office are down 95 percent. I think it&#8217;s almost impossible to even describe the scale and scope of that achievement. President Trump, within days of taking office, cut border crossings 95 percent.<br><br>And those few who have dared to cross are being either prosecuted or deported. They&#8217;re either facing significant jail time for trafficking, smuggling, harboring, aiding, impeding, or they&#8217;re being immediately removed from our soil. Either way, at the end of the process, they are going home.<br><br>He has reimplemented Remain in Mexico, and he has obtained historic cooperation from foreign countries all around the world in accepting their deportees back.<br><br>And he has used the United States military to fully seal the southern border with a historic deployment of both active duty and National Guard troops, resumed the building of infrastructure. He has opened up Guantanamo Bay, and he&#8217;s using military aircraft to carry out deportations all across this country.<br><br>And ICE is joining with ATF, DEA, and FBI to carry out the largest deportation operation in American history. The criminals are going home. The border is sealed shut. America is safe, sovereign, proud, and free. We are a nation that everyone in the world understands all across this planet: You do not come here illegally. You will not get in. You will go to jail. You will go home. You will not succeed.<br><br>This is the biggest and most successful change in any area of law enforcement that this nation has ever seen, and he did it in under one month.<br><br>Thank you.<br><br>MR. HASSETT: Should I go?<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Yes, yes.<br><br>MR. HASSETT: Well, thank you, Karoline. Thank you, Stephen.<br><br>You know, one of the things that President Trump cares most about is job creation. And it was about seven years ago I had the honor of joining you in this room for the first time, and it looks like we&#8217;ve created a lot more jobs in the last month. Look at how many people are here. I &#8212; my estimate is about 180 but &#8212; but I didn&#8217;t count.<br><br>So, thank you. It&#8217;s really an honor to be back here. I think that I just want to go over a few things and then hand it off to Mike.<br><br>The first thing is that the President has told us to prioritize fighting inflation, and he had to do that because, as you know, President Biden let inflation get completely out of control. And he did it with policies that made no sense. They made no sense.<br><br>You know, a lot of times, you people say to us &#8212; our friends, the journalists &#8212; you know, Why are you doing that? But &#8212; but, you know, I like to think, Why did they do that? Why did they spend so much money and then &#8212; why did the Fed print so much money so that we had inflation as high as we&#8217;ve ever seen since Jimmy Carter? So, why did they do that?<br><br>So, we&#8217;re addressing inflation. We didn&#8217;t have to address it in the first term, because it was always in the 1s, almost always. But we&#8217;re going to get it back there.<br><br>And how are we doing it? Well, we&#8217;re doing it with a plan that President Trump and I and others have talked about in the Oval that involves, like, every level of fighting inflation.<br><br>First, the macroeconomic level. We&#8217;re cutting spending. We&#8217;re cutting spending in negotiations with people on the Hill. We&#8217;re cutting spending with the advice of our IT consultant, Elon Musk. And then we&#8217;re also looking into supply-side things, like restoring Trump&#8217;s tax cuts, maybe even expensing new factories so that there is an explosion of supply. If you have an explosion of supply and a reduction in government demand, then inflation goes way down.<br><br>And then, one of the things that you want to say is Well, when are you going to see it? Well, the first thing that you&#8217;ll see when the markets believe that we&#8217;re going to get inflation under control is that the 10-year Treasury rate goes down, because that&#8217;s how they think about future expected inflation.<br><br>And so, we&#8217;re still going to see some memory of Biden&#8217;s inflation. It&#8217;s not going to go away in a month. But the 10-year Treasury before the last Consumer Price Index had dropped about 40 basis points. Forty basis points because markets were optimistic about our ability to fight inflation.<br><br>Forty basis points is kind of not a fun thing to say. I &#8212; economists talk that way. I apologize. But the way to think about it is, for a typical mortgage, if that affects the mortgage rate, then it&#8217;s going to save a typical family buying a house about a thousand bucks a year, and that&#8217;s just in our first month.<br><br>Okay. The second thing we&#8217;ve done is we&#8217;ve had a lot of trade talks. In fact, I was just meeting a minister from Mexico with Howard Lutnick just a couple of hours ago. And we&#8217;re talking about reciprocal trade, and we&#8217;re also talking about the fentanyl crisis.<br><br>And so, reciprocal trade is about our government treating other governments the way they treat us. We want trade to be fair. It turns out that Americans have been disadvantaged by foreign governments over and over, and President Trump wants it to stop. And the fact that struck me as most noticeable, when I started to look at what President Trump was asking us to do, is that last year &#8212; last year &#8212; we have data &#8212; U.S. companies paid $370 billion in taxes to foreign governments &#8212; $370 billion. Last year, foreign multinationals paid us $57 billion in taxes.<br><br>We have one quarter of world GDP. They have three quarters of world GDP. And we&#8217;re paying $370. They&#8217;re paying $57. This is not reciprocal. We&#8217;re going to try &#8212; or we&#8217;re going to fix it.<br><br>The other thing that we&#8217;ve done is we&#8217;ve had an all-of-the-above energy approach that&#8217;s led by Doug Burgum and Chris and a really large team &#8212; EPA &#8212; and we&#8217;ve already made so many actions that are going to affect the price of energy and lower inflation.<br><br>We&#8217;ve opened up 625 million acres to energy exploration. We&#8217;ve cut 50 years of red tape that makes it so you can&#8217;t have permits. And we&#8217;ve even made it so that when you go home, if you get a new one, then you can take a shower or flush a toilet or read under a light bulb. We&#8217;re doing that too.<br><br>So &#8212; so, finally, let&#8217;s just think about, like, the facts that we can see right now that we think are awesome. So, guess what? Small-business optimism is &#8212; has go- &#8212; gone up by the most ever since President Trump came in. ISM, which is the measure of what&#8217;s going on in manufacturing, it&#8217;s expanding again for the first time in years. CEO confidence is the highest it&#8217;s been in years. And the reason &#8212; the reason people are thinking this is that our policies give people cause for optimism.<br><br>And then I want to reiterate what Stephen Miller said, because it&#8217;s so important &#8212; and it&#8217;s so important for financial markets to start to digest this &#8212; that if, say, the Treasury secretary or the &#8212; any Cabinet secretary, with Elon Musk, is able to find some savings &#8212; say, $100 billion &#8212; well, in CBO land, that&#8217;s actually, like, about 10 times that or maybe 12 times that over a 10-year window.<br><br>And so, when you&#8217;re thinking about the negotiations right now over reconciliation and thinking about, well, $4 trillion, $5 trillion, well, those numbers, in terms of the savings, are going to end up being small because of all the waste that we&#8217;re finding.<br><br>And so, we&#8217;re incredibly optimistic about the future of inflation and the future of our economy. And we&#8217;re optimistic because we&#8217;re making so much progress so far, and we already see it in market prices.<br><br>And, with that, I&#8217;ll hand it off to Mike.<br><br>MR. WALTZ: All right. Thanks, Kevin.<br><br>Well, good afternoon. What a month and what a sea change in our &#8212; in our foreign policy. In addition to what we&#8217;re doing on the border and restoring American sovereignty, in addition to what we&#8217;re doing in our economy and the job creation and the inflation reduction, we are bringing the world back to where it was at the end of President Trump&#8217;s first term, which is a world of peace, prosperity, and &#8212; and looking forward and getting us out of the chaos that we&#8217;ve just seen over the last four years.<br><br>So, over the last month, just to name a few, I had the honor of sitting in the Oval Office as President Trump spoke with President Putin and then immediately spoke with President Zelenskyy, and both of them said only President Trump could bring both sides to the table, and only President Trump could stop the horrific fighting that has been going on now for the better part of four years and that only President Trump could drive the world back to peace. Both of those leaders said that in back-to-back calls.<br><br>And, of course, we just had our historic talks mediated by our &#8212; our good friends and partners, Saudi Arabia &#8212; we give great thanks to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for hosting &#8212; and sat down for the first time in years with the Russians and talked about a path forward with peace.<br><br>On top of that and one of the things that led to that was a tremendous co- &#8212; confidence-building measure that we had with the release of Marc Fogel. I&#8217;ll remind everyone, the last time that we had an American released from the Russians, either we gave up a deadly spy; pressured our allies to give up a lethal killer; or we released, under the Biden administration, the world&#8217;s most notorious arms dealer, Viktor Bout, who, by the way, had one of his main clients for arms the cartels in &#8212; in Mexico and Central America.<br><br>We gave up none of that. This was released as a confidence-building measure, working with our great Middle East Envoy, Steve Witkoff, and our secretary of State as a first step towards opening these talks and then moving forward towards peace.<br><br>On top of that, we&#8217;ve secured, just in a month, the return of a dozen &#8212; 12 &#8212; American hostages from Russia, from Bulgaria, from Venezuela, the Taliban, and Hamas. Excuse me, that&#8217;s from Belarus, not Bulgaria.<br><br>We also had &#8212; for the first time in quite some time, we took out a senior leader of ISIS, an international financier and recruiter that the military had been trying to take out for quite some time and &#8212; and wasn&#8217;t able to do so, frankly, because of a bureaucratic approval process. President Trump said, Take him out. And that ISIS financier and leader is no longer on this Earth.<br><br>We&#8217;ve also taken action to eliminate other terrorist organizations in the Middle East. We drove &#8212; before the President was even in office, he started talking consequences for people that would hold Americans.<br><br>Heretofore, there&#8217;s been nothing but upside. You take an American, you get some better deal. You take another one, maybe you get a better deal. No more. There is now nothing but downside for taking Americans illegally, either as hostages or illegal detainees.<br><br>And when President Trump sent a very clear message across the Middle East, but particularly to Hamas, that there would be all hell to pay, we suddenly saw a breakthrough. And now we just saw the release of yet another group of hostages. There have been dozens now, including two Americans that we&#8217;ve seen once again reunited with their families.<br><br>As part of the talks with King Abdullah, he offered &#8212; and &#8212; and I think the entire world has graciously accepted &#8212; to take 2,000 sick children, cancer patients, and others out of Gaza. As a humanitarian &#8212; as a humanitarian gesture, 2,000 Gazans will come out of that hellhole that it is, that wasteland that Gaza is right now, with unexploded ordnance, with debris everywhere, with no sewage, with no water. And &#8212; and President Trump has &#8212; has put forward a plan to deal with the practical reality that is 1.8 million Gazans now &#8212; now truly suffering.<br><br>And then, you know, just to bring it back to our own hemisphere, we&#8217;ve seen literally, in the last month &#8212; after years of national security experts, the generals in charge, and others testifying and ringing the alarm bells about &#8212; about the Chinese Communist Party&#8217;s presence in our own hemisphere, particularly in the Panama Canal, we&#8217;re seeing the leadership of Panama step away from the Belt and Road program, move away from China and back towards the United States, and even enter into talks and &#8212; and other negotiations about addressing the ports on either side of the canal.<br><br>And then, finally, last but not least, we&#8217;ve had four world leaders in the White House, in the Oval Office. We&#8217;ve had the prime minister of Japan, the prime minister of India, the king of &#8212; of Jordan, and, of course, the prime minister of Israel just in the last four weeks. And next week, we&#8217;ll have the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and we&#8217;ll have the president of France, Macron.<br><br>So, President Trump is on what we call Trump warp speed. We are all &#8212; we are all honored to be really serving under &#8212; under his leadership and his vision. And truly, you know, when we all say &#8212; and the President himself say &#8212; says, he is a president of peace. He is a president focused on restoring stability. I think the entire world saw what the world would look like without strong American leadership in the last four years.<br><br>And it&#8217;s truly been an honor to get us back to where we were and back on track under President Trump&#8217;s leadership.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Thank you, Mike.<br><br>MR. WALTZ: Mm-hmm.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Thank you. Thank you, everybody. Trump. He is the dealmaker in chief. The war should have been deterred. The war should have never happened, and I have no doubt it would not have happened under President Trump and will stop under President &#8212; President Trump again.<br><br>But I just want to push back on this notion of our European allies not being consulted as we&#8217;ve entered into this process. I already mentioned the immediate phone call President Trump made to President Zelenskyy. He has talked to President Macron of France repeatedly last week. President Macron convened European leaders and then is coming here on Monday. I&#8217;ve talked to Secretary-General Rutte, the &#8212; the leader of NATO, the secretary-general of NATO. We have repeatedly &#8212; oh, by the way, we had half our Cabinet &#8212; seven Cabinet officials, including the vice president, at the Munich Security Conference, all engaging, all listening, and all making sure our allies were heard.<br><br>However, we&#8217;ve also made it clear for years &#8212; decades, even &#8212; that it is unacceptable that the United States and the United States taxpayer continues to bear the burden not only of the cost of the war in Ukraine but of the defense of &#8212; of Europe. We fully support our NATO Allies. We fully support the Article 5 commitment. But it&#8217;s time for our European allies to step up.<br><br>And one of the things that Secretary-General Rutte said on our call was this last couple of weeks have been a real wake-up call. And I asked him, What have you been missing the last couple of years?<br><br>The fact that we are going to enter into a NATO summit this June with a third of our NATO Allies still not meeting the 2 percent minimum, a commitment they made a decade ago &#8212; literally a decade ago &#8212; with a war on their doorstep &#8212; the largest war that they&#8217;re all extremely concerned about &#8212; but yet it&#8217;s Well, somebody else needs to pay. We&#8217;ve got other domestic priorities. It&#8217;s unacceptable. President Trump has made that clear.<br><br>And the minimum needs to be met. We need to be at 100 percent in &#8212; this June at the NATO summit. And we can be friends and allies and have those tough conversations.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Great. Peter.<br><br>Q Thank you, Karoline. I have a Ukraine one and a DOGE one. Who can talk DOGE?<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Stephen, go ahead.<br><br>Q Well, so &#8212; so, Stephen, we&#8217;re hearing about these DOGE dividend checks that would be 20 percent back to taxpayers, 20 percent to pay down the debt. Sixty percent is left. Who gets that?<br><br>MR. MILLER: Well, the way that it works is when you achieve savings, you can either return it to taxpayers, you can return it to our debtors, or it can be cycled into next year&#8217;s budget, and then it just lowers the overall baseline for next year. So, in other words, you can just transfer it into the next fiscal window and then lower the overall spending level. And that means that you can achieve a permanent savings that way, and that reduces the deficit.<br><br>Q And when is it that people might see those checks?<br><br>MR. MILLER: Well, this is all going to be worked on through the reconciliation process with Congress that&#8217;s going underway right now, as you&#8217;ve seen. The Senate is moving a bill. The House is moving a bill. The president has great confidence in both chambers to deliver on his priorities.<br><br>I would just take this opportunity to note that President Trump has made a historic commitment to the working class of this country to fight for a major tax relief and major price relief. And cutting spending, as DOGE is doing, and cutting taxes is the key to delivering on both of those promises. And President Trump is resolutely committed to doing both.<br><br>Q Thank you. And on Ukraine. I guess, this is for Mike.<br><br>MR. WALTZ: Sure.<br><br>Q After the president&#8217;s post on Truth Social yesterday, need to know: Who does he think is more responsible for the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Putin or Zelenskyy?<br><br>MR. It&#8217;s &#8212; its been damaged. It&#8217;s not at its current capacity. If that is restored, it would account for America&#8217;s entire imports of aluminum for an entire year &#8212; that one foundry.<br><br>There are tremendous resources there. Not only is that long-term security for Ukraine, not only do we help them grow the pie with investments, but, you know, we do have an obligation to the American taxpayer in helping them recoup the hundreds of billions that ha- &#8212; that have occurred.<br><br>So, you know, rather than enter &#8212; enter into some constructive conversations about what that deal should be going forward, we got a lot of rhetoric in the media that was &#8212; that was incredibly unfortunate.<br><br>And I could just tell you, Peter, you know, as a veteran, as somebody who&#8217;s been in combat, this war is horrific. (Laughter.)<br><br>(Cross-talk.)<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Sure.<br><br>Q IRS.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: IRS. Okay. Go ahead.<br><br>Q And this would be for either one of you. So, we have reported, several other outlets have reported that about 3,500 people are due to be &#8212; lose their jobs at the IRS by the end of the week. If the goal of these spending cuts across the federal government has been to reduce the debt, why impose some of the deepest cuts we&#8217;ve seen so far at the agency responsible for raising revenue for the federal government?<br><br>MR. HASSETT: Well, I think our objective is to make sure that the employees that we pay are being productive and effective. And there are many, many &#8212; more than 100,000 people working to collect taxes, and not all of them are fully occupied. And the Treasury secretary is studying the matter and feels like 3,500 is a small number and probably can get bigger, especially as we improve the IT at the IRS.<br><br>And so &#8212; so, I think that it&#8217;s absolutely something that is on the table for good reasons. And the point is that &#8212; don&#8217;t just talk about the IRS. Talk about all of government, that there are so many places &#8212; I live in D.C.; you maybe live in D.C. &#8212; where you never &#8212; there &#8212; nobody &#8212; nobody is going into the buildings. People aren&#8217;t commuting because nobody is doing their job. We look back and we see that there are all these people doing two jobs while they&#8217;re getting a government payroll &#8212; on the payroll.<br><br>So, the point is, we&#8217;re fixing that, and the IRS is a small part of that picture.<br><br>Q So, you&#8217;re saying that everybody who&#8217;s being let go was doing a bad job?<br>MR. HASSETT: I&#8217;m saying that we&#8217;re studying every agency and deciding who to let go and why, and we&#8217;re doing so very rationally with a lot of support from analysis.<br><br>Q Because were being told by a lot of people who have been let go at other agencies that they were told they were being dismissed because of poor performance, when, in some cases, they haven&#8217;t even had a performance review yet because they&#8217;ve only been on the job a couple of months.<br><br>MR. HASSETT: Yeah, I&#8217;ve never seen a person who was laid off for poor performance say that they were performing poorly. (Laughter.) Okay?<br>Q Karoline.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Good point. Sure, Kaitlan.<br><br>Q I have a question. I&#8217;ll start with you, Kevin Hassett. Thank you for being here. And then I&#8217;ve got a question for Mr. Waltz.<br><br>On these potential checks that you might send out from DOGE, is there a concern, as you&#8217;re thinking through this, that they could be inflationary?<br><br>MR. HASSETT: Oh, absolutely not, because imagine if we don&#8217;t spend government money and we give it back to people, then the &#8212; you know, if they spend it all, then you&#8217;re even. But they&#8217;re probably going to save a lot of it, in which case, you&#8217;re reducing inflation.<br><br>Q Okay. So, youre not &#8212;<br><br>MR. HASSETT: And also, when the government spends a lot, that&#8217;s what creates inflation. We learned that from Joe Biden. And so, if we reduce government spending, then that&#8217;s &#8212; you know, reduces inflation. And if you give people money, then they&#8217;re going to save a bunch of it. And &#8212; and when they save it, then that also reduces demand and reduces inflation.<br><br>Q Okay. So, you&#8217;re not worried about it.<br><br>MR. HASSETT: No, Im not.<br><br>Q And, Mr. Waltz, to follow up on Peter&#8217;s question, you wrote in an op-ed in the fall of 2023 that, quote, Putin is to blame, certainly, like al Qaeda was to blame for 9/11.<br><br>MR. WALTZ: Mm-hmm.<br><br>Q Do you still feel that way now, or do you share the president&#8217;s assessment, as he says Ukraine is to blame for the start of this war?<br><br>MR. WALTZ: Well, it shouldn&#8217;t surprise you that I share the president&#8217;s assessment on all kinds of issues. What I wrote as a Member of Congress is &#8212; was as a former Member of Congress.<br><br>Look, what I share the president&#8217;s assessment on is that the war has to end. And what comes with that? What comes with that should be, at some point, elections. What comes with that should be peace. What comes with that is prosperity that we&#8217;ve just offered in this natural resources and economic partnership arrangement: an end to the killing and European security and security for the world. The President is not only determined to do that in Europe, he&#8217;s determined to do it in the Middle East.<br><br>And just a few months ago, we had an administration that had tried for 15 months, week after week, sitting with you here, and couldn&#8217;t get us to a ceasefire, couldn&#8217;t get our hostages out. Now we&#8217;re at that point. We&#8217;re back to the maximum pressure on Iran.<br><br>And we will &#8212; we have just begun, and we will drive towards a ceasefire and all of those other steps. I&#8217;m not going to pre-negotiate or get ahead of the sequencing of all of that. It&#8217;s a very delicate situation.<br><br>But this is a president of peace. And who here would argue against peace?<br><br>Q Okay. So, you do share that assessment.<br><br>And can I follow up. In 2017 &#8212;<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: No. Go ahead, Jordan.<br><br>Q &#8212; then-President Trump &#8212;<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Go ahead, Jordan.<br><br>Q Can I just follow up really quickly?<br><br>Q Thank you. So &#8212;<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: You just had two questions, Kaitlan.<br><br>Q May I &#8212; can I just &#8212;<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Jordan, go ahead.<br><br>Q Mr. &#8212; Mr. Hassett &#8212;<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Thank you.<br><br>Q I have an important follow-up for Mike Waltz.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Jordan, go ahead. Go ahead.<br><br>Q So, Mr. Hassett, you were speaking about tariff revenue, and you also addressed a question about the R- &#8212; IRS. President Trump has spoken about replacing income tax with tariff revenue, especially with all this waste, fraud, and abuse that we&#8217;re seeing cut. Is that a possibility?<br><br>MR. HASSETT: Absolutely. And, in fact, if you think about the China tariff revenue that we&#8217;re estimating is coming in from the 10 percent that we just added, plus the de minimis thing, that it&#8217;s between $500 billion and a trillion dollars over 10 years, is our estimate. And that&#8217;s something that is outside of the reductions that markets are seeing through the negotiations up on the Hill.<br><br>And so, we expect that the tariff revenue is actually going to make it much easier for Republicans to pass a bill, and that was the President&#8217;s plan all along.<br><br>Thank you.<br><br>Q And I &#8212; I have a question for Stephen Miller about DOGE. So, you &#8212; you spoke about DOGE. You said roughly $50 billion is set to be cut in a year of waste, fraud, and abuse by unelected bureaucrats. We&#8217;re hearing this ironic narrative from the President&#8217;s critics and the left-wing media that Elon Musk is an unelected bureaucrat, and he&#8217;s doing all this terrible stuff. Isn&#8217;t one of DOGEs objectives to get &#8212; get rid of the federal bureaucracy, the &#8212; the deep state? And also, who was running the White House when Joe Biden was in office &#8212;<br><br>MR. MILLER: (Laughs.)<br><br>Q &#8212; because I don&#8217;t know a single person who believes it was Joe Biden?<br><br>MR. MILLER: Yes. You&#8217;re &#8212; youre tempting me to say &#8212; (laughs) &#8212; some very harsh things about some of our media friends. The &#8212; yes, it is true that many of the people in this room, for four years, failed to cover the fact that Joe Biden was mentally incompetent and was not running the country.<br><br>It is also true that many people in this room who have used this talking point that Elon is not elected fail to understand how government works. So, I&#8217;m glad for the opportunity for a brief civics lesson.<br><br>A president is elected by the whole American people. He&#8217;s the only official in the entire government that is elected by the entire nation. Right? Judges are appointed. Members of Congress are elected at the district or state level. Just one man.<br><br>And the Constitution, Article Two, has a clause, known as the vesting clause, and it says, The executive power shall be vested in a president, singular. The whole will of democracy is imbued into the elected president. That president then appoints staff to then impose that democratic will onto the government.<br><br>The threat to democracy &#8212; indeed, the existential threat to democracy &#8212; is the unelected bureaucracy of lifetime, tenured civil servants who believe they answer to no one, who believe they can do whatever they want without consequence, who believe they can set their own agenda no matter what Americans vote for.<br><br>So, Americans vote for radical FBI reform, and FBI agents say they don&#8217;t want to change. Or Americans vote for radical reform in our energy policies, but EPA bureaucrats say they don&#8217;t want to change. Or Americans vote to end DEI &#8212; racist DEI policies, and lawyers in the Department of Justice say they don&#8217;t want to change.<br><br>What President Trump is doing is he is removing federal bureaucrats who are defying democracy by failing to implement his lawful orders, which are the will of the whole American people.<br><br>Thank you.<br><br>Q Thanks, Stephen. Can I follow up?<br><br>Q Karoline.<br><br>MS. LEAVITT: Thank you very much, everybody. I&#8217;m looking at the clock. We&#8217;ve almost had an hour of time.<br><br>(Cross-talk.)<br><br>LEAVITT: I know a couple of these individuals have a meeting to get to at 2:00 p.m. So, you&#8217;re welcome to follow up with my team for further questions. We&#8217;re going to let these guys get back to running the United States government.<br><br>And we will see you all later. President Trump will be speaking at 3 o&#8217;clock at the Black History Month reception.<br><br>So, thank you. Its good to see you. We&#8217;ll see you in a bit. Thanks.<a href="00 p.m. So,
you're welcome to follow up with my team for further questions. We're
going to let these guys get back to running the United States government.

And we will see you all later. President Trump will be speaking at 3
o'clock at the Black History Month reception.

So, thank you. Its good to see you. We'll see you in a bit.
Thanks."><br></a><br>Q Are you going to the Black History Month reception, Mr. Miller?<br><br>Q Stephen, on the fraud. Should we expect indictments?<br><br>Q What is your reaction to Mitch McConnells retirement?<br><br>Q Are there indictments coming for all the fraud weve found?<br><br> MR. MILLER: Id love to follow up with you. Just set up a time with Karoline.<br><br> Q Okay. Thank you.<br><br>END   1:56 P.M. EST</p>

{"config":{"whitehouse-header":{"menuOpenTitle":"Open menu","menuCloseTitle":"Close menu","menuOpenLabel":"Menu","menuCloseLabel":"Close","searchOpenTitle":"Open search","searchCloseTitle":"Close search","searchOpenLabel":"Search","searchCloseLabel":"Close","backLabel":"Back"}},"state":{"whitehouse-header":{"popoverOpen":false,"popoverTarget":null,"sticky":false}}}

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerHTML = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

	var userId = 0;

	wp.data

} )();
</script>

<path d="M220.348 428.216C216.351 428.216 213.088 427.171 210.558 425.081C208.028 422.991 206.469 420.113 205.883 416.446H213.143C213.473 418.39 214.279 419.893 215.563 420.956C216.883 422.02 218.423 422.551 220.183 422.551C222.126 422.551 223.703 421.91 224.913 420.626C226.159 419.343 226.783 417.363 226.783 414.686C226.783 412.083 226.178 410.121 224.968 408.801C223.794 407.445 222.218 406.766 220.238 406.766C218.954 406.766 217.799 407.041 216.773 407.591C215.746 408.141 214.976 408.911 214.463 409.901H207.973L209.898 388.066H232.063V393.731H212.813L216.333 392.741L215.233 406.326L213.033 405.941C213.913 404.585 215.049 403.503 216.443 402.696C217.836 401.89 219.596 401.486 221.723 401.486C224.253 401.486 226.453 402.036 228.323 403.136C230.229 404.236 231.714 405.776 232.778 407.756C233.878 409.7 234.428 412.046 234.428 414.796C234.428 417.62 233.841 420.04 232.668 422.056C231.494 424.036 229.863 425.558 227.773 426.621C225.683 427.685 223.208 428.216 220.348 428.216Z" fill="white" />
<path d="M188.02 427.666V417.216L188.35 416.116V393.511L191.1 394.721L174.82 416.556L171.685 413.971H199.625V419.636H168.605V414.191L188.24 388.066H195.335V427.666H188.02Z" fill="white" />
<line x1="261.93" y1="369.881" x2="261.93" y2="446.402" stroke="white" stroke-opacity="0.4" stroke-width="2.39129" />
<path d="M329.486 427.942C330.036 421.672 331.558 415.585 334.051 409.682C336.544 403.778 339.899 398.132 344.116 392.742L344.226 394.007H322.336V388.342H350.716V393.457C348.076 397.27 345.802 401.047 343.896 404.787C342.026 408.49 340.523 412.248 339.386 416.062C338.286 419.875 337.589 423.835 337.296 427.942H329.486Z" fill="white" />
<path d="M306.45 427.942V417.492L306.78 416.392V393.787L309.53 394.997L293.25 416.832L290.115 414.247H318.055V419.912H287.035V414.467L306.67 388.342H313.765V427.942H306.45Z" fill="white" />

		<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__content">
			
							<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__eyebrow">
					<a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/remarks/">Remarks<svg class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__eyebrow--icon" width="11" height="11" viewBox="0 0 11 11" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
<path d="M0.724808 1.45055C0.732563 0.940756 1.15149 0.539597 1.66097 0.554084L8.18243 0.73743C8.43709 0.74459 8.66622 0.854307 8.83047 1.02583C8.99471 1.19735 9.09441 1.43101 9.09053 1.68575C9.08278 2.19554 8.66385 2.5967 8.15436 2.58221L3.85933 2.46146L10.0157 8.89043C10.3703 9.2608 10.3618 9.84465 9.99583 10.1951C9.62987 10.5455 9.04621 10.5288 8.69154 10.1584L2.5352 3.72945L2.46984 8.02568C2.46209 8.53547 2.04316 8.93663 1.53368 8.92214C1.02419 8.90766 0.617659 8.48345 0.625575 7.97383L0.724808 1.45055Z" fill="currentColor" />
</svg>
</a>				</div>
			
							<h1 class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__headline">
					REMARKS BY PRESIDENT TRUMP <br>AT REPUBLICAN GOVERNORS ASSOCIATION MEETING				</h1>
			
			
				<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta">
					<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta--byline-subcategory">
						
<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-byline-subcategory">
	The White House</div>
					</div>
					
					<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta--date">
						<div class="wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2025-02-20T14:02:01-05:00">February 20, 2025</time></div>					</div>
				</div>

			
					</div>
	</div>
</div>



<p class="has-text-align-center">The National Building Museum</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center">Washington, D.C.</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center">(February 20, 2025)</p>



<p>7:37 P.M. EST</p>



<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Well, thank you very much.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thats such a great song.&nbsp; Its hard to cut it off, isnt it?&nbsp; You know?&nbsp;</p>



<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I want to get you home for the hockey game, I guess.&nbsp; And well get this done real quick &#8212; quickly.&nbsp; And I want to thank you all.&nbsp; We have so many great friends here.&nbsp; A lot of great governors, a lot of talent.&nbsp; Im thrilled to be with the Republican governors, and they have done an amazing job, and I look forward to working with each and every one of you as we complete the mission of saving America &#8212; they left us a real mess, didnt they, huh? &#8212; and making our country great again.&nbsp; Were going to do it.&nbsp; Weve made a lot of progress.</p>



<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Were given credit for having the best four weeks that anybody has ever had as an opening, so &#8212; (applause).&nbsp; Now, a few hundred more weeks like this and we&#8217;re going to be in great shape.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we&#8217;ve had a lot of fun doing it too.&nbsp; It&#8217;s a pleasure to do it.&nbsp; We just ripped down whatever they&#8217;ve done.&nbsp; It&#8217;s almost like I want to just do one executive order: Anything he signed is now terminated.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp; It&#8217;s easier than, you know, point after point after point.&nbsp; I sign and sign.&nbsp; Just do one: Everything he signed is no good.&nbsp; Because that&#8217;s really what, basically, it&#8217;s all about.</p>



<p>I especially want to thank the chairman of the Republican Governors Association, Brian Kemp, who is fantastic.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; He was fantastic.&nbsp; We won Georgia by a lot.&nbsp; Where is Brian?&nbsp; We won Georgia by a lot.&nbsp; Where are you, Brian?&nbsp; There you are.&nbsp; And we did a great job together, and I appreciate it.&nbsp; We won&#8217;t forget it.&nbsp; Thank you, Brian.</p>



<p>As well as Vice Chairman Greg Gianforte, a friend of mine who has done a fantastic job as governor &#8212; (applause) &#8212; for organizing this beautiful evening.</p>



<p>In addition to &#8212; hi, Greg.&nbsp; How you doing?&nbsp; Good?&nbsp; You look good.&nbsp; (Laughs.)&nbsp; You look good.</p>



<p>In addition to our fantastic governors, we also have Secretaries Doug Burgum and Chris Wright.&nbsp; They are very important.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Where are they?&nbsp; Where are they?&nbsp; Doug, you were great on television.&nbsp; Chris.&nbsp; These two guys are going to do it.&nbsp; I tell you, if they get the energy bumping, we&#8217;ll get that energy price down, and everything is going to follow.&nbsp; Everything is going to follow, and we&#8217;re going to work very, very hard.</p>



<p>Here&#8217;s a gentleman from Virginia that I recognize that we&#8217;ve become &#8212; (applause) &#8212; we almost won that, didn&#8217;t we, huh?&nbsp; We almost won it.&nbsp; We were just a little bit shy, but I want to thank you for the help.&nbsp; We did a great job together.</p>



<p>But another man that&#8217;s with us is really unbelievable, and you&#8217;re going to be working him very closely: RNC Chairman Michael Whatley.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And Michael worked with Lara, and the team of him and Lara were pretty unbeatable, I would say.&nbsp; She was great and had the victory, and she&#8217;s solid.&nbsp;</p>



<p>There was no nepotism either.&nbsp; Nobody said, Oh, gee.&nbsp; They said, How did you get her?&nbsp; And I said to Michael, So, who would you like to work with?&nbsp; Well, how about Lara again?&nbsp; But Lara came &#8212; right after we won, she said, Now, Dad, I want to go home to my family.&nbsp; (Laughs.)&nbsp; She did a great job, and she just wanted to go back home to the family.</p>



<p>But what a team that was.&nbsp; We beat them left and right.&nbsp; They tried to cheat, but they &#8212; (laughs) how many lawyers did you have?&nbsp; Like, 2,000 lawyers or some crazy number, right?</p>



<p>PARTICIPANT:&nbsp; Six thousand five hundred.</p>



<p>THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Six thousand five hundred lawyers.&nbsp; I would say that&#8217;s a lot.&nbsp; And the reason I picked him is because, with North Carolina, in 2020 &#8212; we did so great in 2020.&nbsp; But the one that just held steady was him with the 601 lawyers at that time.&nbsp; And I remembered that.&nbsp; And I said, That&#8217;s the guy, because we&#8217;re going to win.&nbsp; But we have to keep them from being really bad, being naughty.&nbsp; They tried.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But, you know, we had an expression: We got to make it too big to rig.&nbsp; And that&#8217;s what we did.&nbsp; Too big to rig.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And it was a great night.</p>



<p>And, Michael, thank you.&nbsp; Great &#8212; just a fantastic job.&nbsp; You&#8217;ll be working with these ladies and gentlemen on just keeping &#8212; keeping everything, including keeping governors seats, I assume.&nbsp; You&#8217;re going to work with them on governors seats too, right?</p>



<p>But there&#8217;s no better man than Michael.&nbsp; Thank you, Michael.&nbsp; Great job.&nbsp; Appreciate it.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>And were gathered tonight at a really exciting time in our nation.&nbsp; I think it&#8217;s going to be a very exciting time.&nbsp; We have tremendous potential.&nbsp; I have been called by every company &#8212; Brian just told me about a big one that&#8217;s going to be moving in in a very big way.&nbsp; But I have been called by so many big companies that they want to beat the tariffs, and there&#8217;s only one way to beat the tariffs.</p>



<p>Tariffs, one of the most beautiful words I&#8217;ve ever heard.&nbsp; In fact, I went around saying its my favorite word in the dictionary, and I got killed by the fake news media.&nbsp; They said, What about God?&nbsp; What about religion?&nbsp; What about love?&nbsp; I said, All right.&nbsp; I give up.&nbsp; It&#8217;s my fourth favorite word.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; So, now I say God, religion, love, and then tariffs, number four.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp; And now I&#8217;m okay.&nbsp; I can get away with that.&nbsp; I couldn&#8217;t get away with making it number one, but it&#8217;s close.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>The American people gave Republicans a historic mandate in November &#8212; you remember that, November 5th &#8212; what a day that was, huh?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; No &#8212; there was no games.&nbsp; November 5th, 2024, will go down as one of the most important days in the history of our country.&nbsp; I believe that.</p>



<p>We won the House.&nbsp; We won the Senate.&nbsp; We won the White House.&nbsp; And, in the presidential race, we won all seven swing states by a lot, and the popular vote by millions and millions of votes for the first time of any Republican in decades.&nbsp; It&#8217;s hard for us to win the popular vote, but it&#8217;s not going to be anymore, because we&#8217;re a much different Republican Party right now.</p>



<p>We&#8217;re really &#8212; nobody can believe what&#8217;s happened to this party.&nbsp; Its become a big party, really big and powerful party.</p>



<p>We won 85 percent of all counties in America.&nbsp; Think of that.&nbsp; Eighty-five percent.&nbsp; Have you seen the map?&nbsp; It&#8217;s all red.&nbsp; There&#8217;s a little blue on the outside here and &#8212; the outside.&nbsp; The whole thing is, like, red.&nbsp;</p>



<p>They won 525 counties compared to us &#8212; 2,600 counties.&nbsp; Think of that.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t know why we only won by millions of votes.&nbsp; We should have won by a lot more than that.&nbsp; Maybe it&#8217;s because they cheated.&nbsp; Who knows?</p>



<p>And incredibly, all 50 states shifted toward the Republican Party.&nbsp; That&#8217;s never happened before.&nbsp; It&#8217;s the first time ever in history that that&#8217;s happened.&nbsp; All 50 states shifted toward the Republicans &#8212; and significantly, in many cases.</p>



<p>Most importantly for this room, we&#8217;re pleased to welcome eight new Republican governors.&nbsp; Could you stand up please?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Just stand up.&nbsp; Look at these people.&nbsp; Oh, I know them.&nbsp; I know the men.&nbsp; Good.&nbsp; Great.&nbsp; I know every one of them.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>Mike Braun of Indiana.&nbsp; Mike Kehoe of Missouri.&nbsp; Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire.&nbsp; Larry Rhoden &#8212; that&#8217;s great &#8212; Larry Rhoden of South Dakota.&nbsp; Kelly Armstrong of North Dakota.&nbsp; Patrick Morrisey of West Virginia.&nbsp; Jenniffer Gonzlez-Coln of Puerto Rico.&nbsp; Nikolao Pula of American Samoa.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And I want to congratulate you all.&nbsp; You had great races.&nbsp; You won, generally, pretty easily.&nbsp; We&#8217;re going to win a lot of races.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, in presidential races, they say when you win the presidency, usually the midterms don&#8217;t go well.&nbsp; I think we&#8217;re going to do great.&nbsp; I think we&#8217;re going to really increase our margins by a lot.&nbsp;</p>



<p>That&#8217;s why I went to Michael.&nbsp; I said, You got to stay.&nbsp; You can&#8217;t go anywhere, Michael.</p>



<p>But I can tell you that I did something very different.&nbsp; Our win was so big and so conclusive presidentially &#8212; and we had great help from donors.&nbsp; We have a lot of great donors in the room tonight, but &#8212;</p>



<p>This is a nice room, by the way.&nbsp; Its a very nice place.</p>



<p>But we did something differently.&nbsp; I said that &#8212; to my people that do the fundraising, I said, Listen, everyone is so happy.&nbsp; Usually, you wait two or three years to go back to the donors.&nbsp; You know, you let it rest.&nbsp; You let their wallets cool off a little bit.&nbsp; But I did it the next morning after we won.&nbsp;(laughter).</p>



<p>I said to Meredith, who may or may not be here &#8212; I don&#8217;t think she is.&nbsp; Maybe she is.&nbsp; She&#8217;s great and &#8212; but I said to a whole staff of people &#8212; I said, Call everybody and see if they&#8217;ll double up.</p>



<p>Now, we raised a billion six.&nbsp; They raised $2.7 billion, and they&#8217;re running short.&nbsp; They can&#8217;t raise the final 28.&nbsp; You know, when you lose, it&#8217;s very hard to raise money.&nbsp; But when you win, it&#8217;s not so hard.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I said, See what you can do.&nbsp; Call everybody and say, Thank you very much.&nbsp; We appreciate it.&nbsp; Would you like to make a contribution?&nbsp; (Laughs.)</p>



<p>So, this was not a good situation, but they fully understood.&nbsp; They were so happy, they didn&#8217;t care.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And, Michael, we raised $608 million in three weeks.&nbsp; Can you believe that?&nbsp; Six &#8212; so we&#8217;ve got that money, and I got to spend it somewhere.&nbsp; And they tell me I&#8217;m not allowed to run.&nbsp; I&#8217;m not sure.&nbsp; Is that true?&nbsp; I&#8217;m not sure.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>So, if I can&#8217;t spend it on me, I guess that means I&#8217;m going to be spending it on some of my friends, right?&nbsp; A lot of my friends who are going to be running.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>But think of that.&nbsp; We raised $608 million.&nbsp; Isn&#8217;t that great?&nbsp; And I think I&#8217;ll keep going.&nbsp; I&#8217;ll just keep bugging them, bugging them, build it up.&nbsp; But its going to be great.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I think we&#8217;re going to do fantastically.&nbsp; I think the midterms are going to be a big surprise.&nbsp; And it just seems &#8212; I don&#8217;t know what it is.&nbsp; You go back to the last, I think, eight elections in a row, the midterms haven&#8217;t been great for the person that wins the presidency.&nbsp; And I think, so far, we&#8217;re very popular.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I had an approval rating today of 71 and another one of 69.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I have not heard of those numbers before.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we&#8217;re going to fight very hard, because the better I do, the better you do.&nbsp; It makes your races a lot easier if we do well, and we&#8217;re going to keep doing well.</p>



<p>With the help of everyone here tonight, the golden age of America has officially begun and the golden age of &#8212; just this whole thing &#8212; the red states &#8212; it&#8217;s going to be leading the way to making our country richer and safer and stronger than ever before.&nbsp;</p>



<p>The red states are going to do good.&nbsp; And the blue states &#8212; I don&#8217;t know &#8212; maybe they&#8217;ll totally disappear off that map.</p>



<p>You know, they don&#8217;t learn, because &#8212; you know, like men in women&#8217;s sports.&nbsp; I say weve become the party of common sense.&nbsp; Men in women&#8217;s sports is not a winner for them.&nbsp; But I saw somebody fighting like hell for the fact that a man should partake in women&#8217;s sports &#8212; a Democrat, a radical left lunatic.&nbsp; And they&#8217;re still going at it.</p>



<p>And we shouldn&#8217;t really fight them too hard until just about a week or two before the election.&nbsp; Just let them go.&nbsp; Don&#8217;t convince them not to.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, I&#8217;m always saying, They haven&#8217;t learned.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t want to say that.&nbsp; Don&#8217;t say that.&nbsp; Let them keep going.&nbsp; And then about a week before the election, just blast the hell out of them.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)</p>



<p>It&#8217;s like in a race.&nbsp; You know, you hang in there, and then you just go.&nbsp; Because there&#8217;s no way &#8212; open borders with prisoners coming in.&nbsp; Jails.&nbsp; Some of the worst murderers in the world.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We had &#8212; one guy killed five people &#8212; separately killed five different people.&nbsp; This is not going to be a great person for our county.</p>



<p>But we had 11,088 murderers right now.&nbsp; Some of them have been already brought back.&nbsp; And you know, when you think about it, transgender everything.&nbsp; Everybody should be transgender.&nbsp; These are not things that play very well.&nbsp; I would say they&#8217;re 7 percent issues for them, and they&#8217;re over 90 percent for us.&nbsp; But they keep going.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, don&#8217;t tell them they&#8217;re wrong.&nbsp; It&#8217;s too long.&nbsp; Two years or four years.&nbsp; Its too long.&nbsp; Let them continue to go and say, I think it&#8217;s a brilliant idea to have open borders, to allow prisons and mental institution people to pour in from all over the world.&nbsp; Everywhere.&nbsp; They came from everywhere.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But about a week before that election, go crazy.&nbsp; Just save up your money and explain we can&#8217;t live like this.&nbsp; And they understand it.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Every day of my administration will be fighting to help your state succeed and prosper.&nbsp; And together, we&#8217;re going to bring back the American dream &#8212; something nobody talks about anymore.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In our last four weeks, our new administration has accomplished more than most administrations do in four years, and the last administration was a negative.&nbsp; I mean, it was accomplishment &#8212; I would say negative 50 percent.&nbsp; There wasn&#8217;t any accomplishment.&nbsp; There was de-accomplishment.&nbsp;</p>



<p>On day one, I declared a national emergency on our southern border.&nbsp; I sent our military to the border to secure the sovereign territory of the United States of America.&nbsp; We ended catch and release.&nbsp; We began the largest deportation operation in American history, larger even than that of President Dwight D. Eisenhower.&nbsp; You know, he was sort of a moderate guy, but he was very strong on the fact he didn&#8217;t want people pouring into our country from all over the world.&nbsp; He was very tough.&nbsp; He had the record.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We now have the record.&nbsp; Its not a record I&#8217;m really proud of.&nbsp; You don&#8217;t like to do that, but we have no choice.&nbsp; We can&#8217;t let it &#8212; I mean, they let criminals &#8212; many, many criminals &#8212; hundreds of thousands, probably millions of criminals.&nbsp; Twenty-one million people, I believe, is the number.&nbsp; And of that, millions of people are hard, stone-cold criminals.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In the past four weeks, illegal border crossings have plummeted by nearly 100 percent, and the tiny number of illegals that do make it across are being apprehended and sent right back to their home, where they belong.&nbsp; All countries are taking the illegal aliens back &#8212; every single one, even though they said, and strongly, We&#8217;re never taking them back.&nbsp; Don&#8217;t even try.&nbsp; They said that during the Biden administration.&nbsp; It didn&#8217;t work.&nbsp;</p>



<p>They&#8217;re taking them back.&nbsp; They have no choice.&nbsp; They&#8217;re taking them back.&nbsp; They know we&#8217;re not playing games.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>You remember Venezuela saying it: We&#8217;re not taking them back.&nbsp; Don&#8217;t even waste your time.&nbsp; They said that to Biden.&nbsp; He said, Well, they have us over a barrel.&nbsp; They don&#8217;t have us over a barrel.&nbsp;</p>



<p>How about BRICS?&nbsp; You know, the BRICS states?&nbsp; There are, like, six of them, and they were trying to destroy our dollar.&nbsp; They were going to say &#8212; you know, they wanted to create a new currency.&nbsp; They probably wanted to use the yuan, China.&nbsp; They wanted to use the yuan.&nbsp; And Biden said, Well, this is a tough situation.&nbsp; There&#8217;s not much we can do about that.&nbsp; We can&#8217;t help that.&nbsp; I said, Oh, we can help it.</p>



<p>So, when I came in, the first thing I said is: Any BRICS state that even mentions the destruction of the dollar will be charged a 150 percent tariff.&nbsp; And we don&#8217;t want your goods.&nbsp; We don&#8217;t want to partake.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And the BRICS states just broke up.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t know what the hell happened to them.&nbsp; We haven&#8217;t heard from the BRICS states lately.</p>



<p>But he said that wasn&#8217;t much we could do about it.&nbsp; There was a lot.&nbsp; It took once &#8212; literally.&nbsp; They said, Sir, what about the BRICS states?&nbsp; Theyre going to take over the dollar, the sanctity of the dollar.&nbsp; They&#8217;re going to create a new currency to rule the world.&nbsp; I said, No, they&#8217;re not.&nbsp; They said, Yes, they are, sir.&nbsp; They said it.&nbsp; I said, No, they&#8217;re not.&nbsp; Tell them 150 percent tariff, plus we&#8217;re not going to do business with them, and that includes China.</p>



<p>And all of a sudden, they went to the BRICS states, and they said, Could I ask you, how do you feel about the &#8212; I have no comment on this.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t know what you&#8217;re even talking about.&nbsp; It was an amazing turnaround.&nbsp;</p>



<p>No, we&#8217;re not playing games.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Just this week, I officially designated the drug cartels as foreign terrorist organizations, including Tren de Aragua and MS-13, which gives us great power.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And to facilitate the rapid deportation of the worst criminals that we have anywhere in the world, we&#8217;ve also opened the full capacity of the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay.&nbsp; You know, people don&#8217;t realize that thing was built &#8212; you know, we hear about a few prisoners, and they do have maximum security, but it holds &#8212; actually, it was built for thousands and thousands of people, and we&#8217;re using that prior to bringing back to their country.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We use it for the bad ones, the really bad ones.&nbsp; And in some cases, they&#8217;re so bad, we don&#8217;t want them to go back to the country.&nbsp; We want to watch them, because they&#8217;ll be able &#8212; if they do sneak in, we don&#8217;t want that.&nbsp; We don&#8217;t want them anywhere near our country.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In addition, we&#8217;re waging war on Joe Biden&#8217;s inflation disaster, the worst inflation probably in our history.&nbsp; They say 48 years, which isn&#8217;t bad, but probably in our history.&nbsp; And to bring down the price of energy, I declared a national energy emergency.&nbsp; It&#8217;s going to be an emergency.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And you know what our &#8212; what we say and what Doug is going to do &#8212; Doug, you are so important, you and Chris.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, Chris is known &#8212; and I got this from Doug &#8212; as the best energy guy in the entire country.&nbsp; And people were shocked that he wanted to do this.&nbsp; He gave up something tremendous.&nbsp; He was the biggest guy.&nbsp; There was nobody bigger, nobody better than Chris Wright.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Is Chris Wright here?&nbsp; Is he here?&nbsp; Where is he?&nbsp; This guy is &#8212; and this is from Doug.&nbsp;I said, Doug, I want to make you the Energy czar.&nbsp; And he said, Sir, there&#8217;s one man that blows me away.&nbsp; Right, Doug?&nbsp; He said, His name is Chris Wright.&nbsp; He&#8217;s much better.&nbsp; I said, I want to see this man, and I met him.&nbsp; And I just agreed immediately that he was far superior to Doug.&nbsp; I&#8217;m only kidding.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>So, what I did &#8212; we have a weird deal.&nbsp; You know, we have the Department of Energy and the Department of the Interior, and Interior has all of the energy.&nbsp; And Doug has none of the energy, but he&#8217;s got &#8212; Chris has none of the energy, but he got a hell of a good title.&nbsp; But we want the guy with the energy to be able to drill, so we sort of merged them.&nbsp; And theyre friends and everything else, and they&#8217;ve got a thing going on.&nbsp; I think it&#8217;s going to set records like nobody&#8217;s ever seen before.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we have the man that controls the energy, we have the man that drills the energy, and now weve put them together, and you&#8217;re going to see some action.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; You&#8217;re going to see something come way down.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, thank you.&nbsp; And thank you, Doug.&nbsp; You were really a terrific &#8212; he was a great governor, by the way.&nbsp; A couple of you may know him slightly.&nbsp; But he was a great governor.&nbsp; Did a fantastic job.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, he made a lot of money in the technology business.&nbsp; Sold to Microsoft for a lot of money.&nbsp; I won&#8217;t tell you how much.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t want to embarrass him.&nbsp; Some people would say it&#8217;s a lot.&nbsp; Some people would say it wasn&#8217;t that much, right?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But, you know, when you get close to a billion dollars, that&#8217;s pretty good.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And he didn&#8217;t know much about energy.&nbsp; When he became governor, he became one of the great experts of energy anywhere.&nbsp; We did unbelievable &#8212; really, an unbelievable job with the state.&nbsp; He did like me: He did well in business, and then he said, Let&#8217;s run for politics.&nbsp; And he did, and they love him in the state.&nbsp; But he was term-limited, and I watched him running.&nbsp; It was running against me, but I still liked him.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; And I said, That guy&#8217;s got real talent, and he was one of the first people I called.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, you&#8217;re doing a great job, and thank you for giving us &#8212; for leading us to Chris.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; I&#8217;ll give you a bigger thank you in two years if Chris is as good as you say.&nbsp; Okay?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But I know he&#8217;s going to be.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Thanks a lot, Chris.&nbsp; Good.&nbsp; Go out there.&nbsp;</p>



<p>If we can bring energy down, everything&#8217;s coming down.&nbsp; You know, the eggs are coming down, and the bacon is coming down.&nbsp; Everything is coming down.&nbsp; And that&#8217;s the biggest thing, the energy.&nbsp; So, those two guys are very important.</p>



<p>To cut through the red tape, I&#8217;ve established a National Energy Dominance Council chaired by your former colleague, Secretary Burgum.&nbsp; He&#8217;s going to do a fantastic job.&nbsp; We&#8217;re putting incredible people on it.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I withdrew from the one-sided and very expensive Paris Climate Accord.&nbsp; It&#8217;s a one-way street.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; You know, under that accord, we pay $1 trillion.&nbsp; Think of it.&nbsp; We pay a trillion dollars.&nbsp; They pay nothing.&nbsp; China doesn&#8217;t pay anything.&nbsp; India doesn&#8217;t pay anything.&nbsp; Russia doesn&#8217;t pay.&nbsp; We just pay everybody.&nbsp;</p>



<p>It&#8217;s like a health organization, and every one of the &#8212; every deal is no good, but we&#8217;re changing it.&nbsp; We terminated health &#8212; you know, on the world health, we paid a hundred &#8212; we paid $500 million a year, and China paid $39 million a year.&nbsp; I said, That doesn&#8217;t sound good.&nbsp; They have 1.4 billion people, and we have &#8212; nobody knows what the hell our number is, because so many people pour into our country. &nbsp;We used to say, like, 325.&nbsp; I have no idea.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll figure it out eventually.&nbsp; But let&#8217;s put it this way: It should be substantially less than 1.4.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we have &#8212; let&#8217;s say we have 325 million.&nbsp; They have 1.4.&nbsp; We&#8217;re paying $500 million.&nbsp; And these arent &#8212; I mean, relative to government, these aren&#8217;t huge numbers, but this is an example of what happens when you have bad government, when you have incompetent people.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, I would explain this, and they called me, and they said, We&#8217;ll let you in for the same $39 million.&nbsp; I said, Well, we should be much less than 39.&nbsp; We should be &#8212; but I didn&#8217;t even want to do that, because I&#8217;m not going to talk &#8212; I said, I&#8217;ll think about it.&nbsp; And it was very public.&nbsp; And when Biden came in, he agreed to go back in to the World Health for $500 million.&nbsp; He could have gotten &#8212; I mean, it&#8217;s a lot of money.&nbsp; You could have gotten it for $39 million, Joe.&nbsp; That&#8217;s why you&#8217;re not president any longer, I guess.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>No, he could have had it for 39.&nbsp; They were standing there, Were going to &#8212; it was very public.&nbsp; But he went in &#8212; he took the $500 million instead, because he never laid in bed at night, sweating, tossing and turning, like half of these governors &#8212; not all of them, probably, but half of them.&nbsp; Theyre sweating, How are we going to do a great job?&nbsp; He never did that.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But that&#8217;s just a case study in, you know, how not to run.&nbsp; Because, you know, if we &#8212; if we had people at that level that would have negotiated &#8212; I bought a plane.&nbsp; It&#8217;s really two planes.&nbsp; Air Force One.&nbsp; Now, if Boeing would build a damn thing, it would be nice too.&nbsp; We don&#8217;t build like we used to.&nbsp; We don&#8217;t build too fast.&nbsp; I gave the order out about six years ago.&nbsp; They&#8217;re still waiting.&nbsp; Getting a little tired of it.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I gave a fixed-price deal, but it was $5.7 billion.&nbsp; I negotiated with Boeing.&nbsp; It took about two months, and I got the 5.7 down to $4 billion.&nbsp; Actually, one penny less than 4.&nbsp; I said, It has to have a three on it.&nbsp; And he said, You want from 5.7 to 3?&nbsp; And I said, Yeah, three on it, meaning it has to start with a three.&nbsp; And after about two months of saying, No, no, no, no, it has to have a three.&nbsp; It has to have a three, he called up.&nbsp; He said, Sir, 3 bil- &#8212; what I want, and this is what happened: $3,999,999,999.99.&nbsp; One penny less.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; I said, You have a deal.&nbsp; But we saved $1.7 billion just by negotiating.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And in all fairness, mostly, you can do that.&nbsp; And some of you do do it.&nbsp; Some of you do.&nbsp; You know, you have surplus states.&nbsp; You have incredible states, and you have to do that, because every time somebody sends you a bill, they expect to be negotiated.&nbsp; And in the past administration &#8212; and sometimes, I guess, in this, it happens, because people don&#8217;t care.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, Elon talks about caring.&nbsp; Caring is very important.&nbsp; And they have to care.&nbsp; If they care, they say, No, no, I&#8217;ll pay you &#8212; they&#8217;ll send you a bill for $10,000, and you say, Nope, I&#8217;ll give you five.&nbsp; And they&#8217;ll say, No way, no way, no way, and you&#8217;ll end up paying six or seven or something.&nbsp; But all you have to do is care a little bit and try and get it down.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And literally, every contract.&nbsp; I think, there&#8217;s not a contract that&#8217;s sent in government that I couldn&#8217;t &#8212; and that many of you couldn&#8217;t cut and cut very substantially.&nbsp; And boy, what a difference it would make for the government.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I terminated the Green New Scam, one of the great scams in the history of our country.&nbsp; I canceled Joe Biden&#8217;s insane electric vehicle mandate, saving our auto industry from destruction.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That was an easy one.&nbsp; And all of this helps to combat inflation and bring down costs.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We&#8217;re bringing down costs way down.&nbsp; We&#8217;re going to bring up jobs like you haven&#8217;t seen because the companies pouring in.&nbsp; And we&#8217;re going to have announcements over the next three, four weeks that you&#8217;re not going to believe from some of the biggest companies in the world.&nbsp; And the numbers are staggering: hundreds of billions of dollars of investment, hundreds and hundreds &#8212; trillions of dollars, when you add it up.&nbsp;</p>



<p>To slash hundreds of billions of dollars in waste and fraud, we&#8217;re talking about also &#8212; and abuse &#8212; I&#8217;ve created, as you possibly have read just a little bit, the Department of Government Efficiency.&nbsp; (Applause.) <a>And here are just some of the things that we&#8217;ve paid, and we&#8217;ve stopped, and we&#8217;ve gotten the money back.&nbsp;<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $520 million for a consultant to do ESG &#8212; that&#8217;s environmental, social, and governance investments &#8212; in Africa &#8212; $525 million.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>$40 million to improve the social and economic inclusion of sedentary migrants.&nbsp; Nobody even knows what the hell it means.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>
