<p>$10 million for Mozambique medical male circumcision.&nbsp; We&#8217;re doing circumcisions in Mozambique to the tune of approximately $12 million.&nbsp;</p>



<p>$14 million for improving public procurement in Serbia.</p>



<p><a>$486 million to the Consortium for Elections and Political Process Strengthening, including $22 million for inclusive and participatory political process in Moldova and $21 million for voter turnout in India.&nbsp; Why are we caring about India turnout?&nbsp; We got enough problems.&nbsp; We want our own turnout, don&#8217;t we?&nbsp; Can you imagine, all that money going to India?&nbsp; I wonder what they think when they get it.&nbsp;</a></p>



<p>Now, it&#8217;s a kickback scheme.&nbsp; You know, it&#8217;s not like they get it and they spend &#8212; they kick it back to the people that send it, I would say, in many cases &#8212; many of these cases.&nbsp; Anytime you have no idea what we&#8217;re talking about, that means there&#8217;s a kickback, because nobody has any idea what&#8217;s going on here.&nbsp;</p>



<p>$29 million to strengthen the political landscape in Bangladesh.&nbsp; Nobody knows what they mean by political landscape.&nbsp; What does that mean?</p>



<p>$20 million for fiscal federalism and $19 million for biodiversity in Nepal.&nbsp;</p>



<p>$47 million for improving learning outcomes in Asia.&nbsp; What the hell do I care about?&nbsp; We got a lot.&nbsp; We got enough problems.</p>



<p>And all of this is terminated.&nbsp; We terminated this stuff, and we&#8217;re on the track.&nbsp; And, by the way, so many others I could have &#8212; I could &#8212; I could read all night long.&nbsp; But so many were so terrible, and some &#8212; some were actually disgusting.&nbsp; And I know you&#8217;re eating your dinner, so I didn&#8217;t want to do that.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>But we&#8217;re draining the swamp.&nbsp; And, you know, one of them was $100 million for condoms for Hamas.&nbsp; You heard about that.&nbsp; Fifty and fifty.&nbsp; It&#8217;s $50 million, and then they decided they needed more condoms, so they sent another $50 million.&nbsp; So, it&#8217;s $100 million &#8212; condoms for Hamas.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But now that&#8217;s the good stuff.&nbsp; Here&#8217;s even worse: Social Security.&nbsp; As you know, generally speaking, people don&#8217;t live to be over 100 years old.&nbsp; We all will, I think &#8212; 120, 130, hopefully.&nbsp; But, you know, you hate &#8212; when you get near that number, it&#8217;s like, Let&#8217;s hope we can live to length like this.&nbsp;&nbsp; But here&#8217;s what we&#8217;re finding and what we found, and these were all found by these computer geniuses.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I asked Elon, What trait do these have?&nbsp; You know, they started off with 12 guys, then they had 30 guys, then they had 57 guys.&nbsp; Now they have over 100 guys.&nbsp; And he attracts very young people with high IQs.&nbsp; You know?&nbsp; Some people attract very beautiful people.&nbsp; I think I like them better, actually.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But he attracts young people that are brilliant, and they love the country too.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But I said, What trait do they really have?&nbsp; And the trait that they really have was that they&#8217;re extraordinary with computers.&nbsp; They can take them &#8212; he said, They make love to their computer.&nbsp; I said, I don&#8217;t want to hear about that.&nbsp; Doesn&#8217;t sound too &#8212; (laughter).&nbsp; He said, They can take apart the most complex computer instruments and &#8212; and literally put them back blindfolded.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, when they go into some guy that&#8217;s ripping off the country by doing some of the things you&#8217;ve just heard or what you&#8217;re going to hear, they can&#8217;t be bullshitted.&nbsp; You know?&nbsp; They can&#8217;t say, Oh, gee, there was a mistake.&nbsp; There was a big mistake.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And we&#8217;re finding hundreds of billions of dollars worth of fraud, waste, and abuse.&nbsp; But I think fraud will be the number one as we see.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But listen to this.&nbsp; On the program, there are 4.7 million Social Security members who go and live from 100 to 109.&nbsp; Well, I&#8217;ll tell you, I know some people that are close to 100.&nbsp; I know one or two that got over that mark.&nbsp; But you get &#8212; you don&#8217;t have millions.&nbsp;</p>



<p>3.6 million people from age 110 to age 119.&nbsp; 3.47 million people from age 120 to 129.&nbsp; In other words, 120 to 129 years old, millions of people &#8212; millions.&nbsp; 3.9 million people from age 130 to 139, which is pretty amazing, because the longest-living person ever on record &#8212; and they&#8217;re not sure it was correct &#8212; was a woman from a very faraway place lived to 127 years old.&nbsp; She was a healthy specimen.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But she lived to 127.</p>



<p>3.5 million people from age 140 to 149.&nbsp; So, we have 140-year-old people, plus.&nbsp; Millions of them.&nbsp; 1.3 million people live to over 150 years of age &#8212; 150 to 159, to be exact.&nbsp; Over 130,000 people over the age of 160 years old, including 1,039 people between the ages of 220 to 229.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And we&#8217;re going to be investigating this fraud.&nbsp; The &#8212; actually, we had one person at &#8212; who was 361 years old.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; And what we&#8217;re doing now is we&#8217;re finding how many of these people were paid.&nbsp; So, we have millions of people &#8212; could be well over 100 million people on our Social Security rolls.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, the good news is, when we take them off, whether they were paid or not, it looks like our Social Security could be really solid.&nbsp; It could be a lot better than we thought, if you think about it.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And I&#8217;m going to do something &#8212; I&#8217;m actually going on this one.&nbsp; You know, all my life I&#8217;ve heard about Fort Knox.&nbsp; That&#8217;s where the gold is kept, right?&nbsp; I heard, Fort Knox.&nbsp; Oh, ho, ho.&nbsp; But, you know, we&#8217;re getting a little bit shaky.&nbsp; We&#8217;re getting the yips on this stuff.&nbsp; Like, I want to find out.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we&#8217;re going to open up the doors.&nbsp; I&#8217;m going to see if we have gold there.&nbsp; We want to find out: Did anybody steal the gold in Fort Knox?&nbsp; It&#8217;s a pretty amazing place.</p>



<p>But I&#8217;m going to actually go.&nbsp; We&#8217;re going to open the doors.&nbsp; We&#8217;re going to inspect Fort Knox.&nbsp; We want to make sure that we actually have, you know, 400 tons of gold or whatever the hell it is.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; It&#8217;s a lot of gold.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t want to open it and the cupboards are bare.&nbsp; Could happen.</p>



<p>If you look at some of the things &#8212; oh, by the way, wait until we go into the Education Department.&nbsp; We haven&#8217;t even done that.&nbsp; So, we &#8212; we could find as much as $1.5 trillion worth of waste, fraud, and abuse.&nbsp; If we do that, we can balance budgets.&nbsp; We can do a lot of other things, especially when you couple it with the massive amounts of tariffs that are coming in.<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Already, you know, just with what we are charging &#8212; I won&#8217;t mention the country because I don&#8217;t want to anger people that like me, and I like them very much.&nbsp; But we&#8217;re finding at least $60 billion a year in one country alone.&nbsp; And I haven&#8217;t even started, it&#8217;s just a very small portion that I&#8217;ve, you know, attached to them.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, I got a call from Congress.&nbsp; They said, You know, a lot of money is coming in from these tariffs, and they&#8217;re starting to change their whole thing.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, if you can add the tariffs &#8212; and this is numbers that &#8212; I don&#8217;t want to say it, because then they&#8217;ll say, He didn&#8217;t produce.&nbsp; But you could wipe out your income tax.&nbsp; You could maybe not even have an income tax system when this thing works out.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Because in the old days, that&#8217;s what happened.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, our country was the richest ever from 1870 to 1913.&nbsp; That&#8217;s when we were actually the richest, and we were a full tariff country.</p>



<p>McKinley &#8212; and I just &#8212; by the way, I just renamed Mount McKinley Mount McKinley.&nbsp; I hope you&#8217;re happy about that.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; But McKinley was a president.&nbsp; He was a tariff guy, and he believed that countries should not be allowed to come in and plunder.&nbsp; He would see &#8212; he had beautiful language on tariffs.&nbsp; Plunder our wealth, plunder our jobs, steal our companies, and take without paying a very fair price.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And he said &#8212; and that price should be more than fair.&nbsp; It should be high, because what they do is they hurt our country.&nbsp; And we became very rich.&nbsp; He was assassinated.&nbsp; And, as you know, Roosevelt took over &#8212; Teddy.&nbsp; And he spent money on parks and on dams and on everything.&nbsp; I mean, you know &#8212; but he really spent a lot of the money &#8212; McKinley never got the credit &#8212; but he spent a lot of the money that McKinley made.</p>



<p>But it was the richest we ever were in the 1800s, early 1900s.&nbsp; And then, in 1913, we went to the income tax system.&nbsp; And to be honest, we did fine, but we were never like we were.&nbsp; They formed the tariff commission of 1887, and it was a commission of people like you.&nbsp; Blue bloods.&nbsp; Are you blue bloods?&nbsp; There are a couple in &#8212; about three of them over here.&nbsp; But blue bloods.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But it was a commission, and it was set up for the sole purpose of &#8212; we have so much money.&nbsp; This is in the United States.&nbsp; We don&#8217;t know &#8212; we had no debt.&nbsp; We had no nothing.&nbsp; We had massive amounts of money.&nbsp; The commission was set up to determine where we should spend our money.&nbsp; Where do we spend it?&nbsp; Got so much.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Can you imagine?&nbsp; Wouldn&#8217;t that be nice?&nbsp; Now look at what they&#8217;re doing.&nbsp; But this is money we have to borrow where they&#8217;re doing it.&nbsp; But we&#8217;re going to find out that this money went to people and it got kicked back.&nbsp; You&#8217;re going to find out a lot of that.&nbsp; But we&#8217;ll catch it all.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We&#8217;ve launched the largest deregulation campaign in our country&#8217;s history.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;&nbsp; For every 1 new regulation, I&#8217;ve directed that 10 old regulations must be eliminated.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And I will say, in my first term, we did more deregulation than any president in history, by far.&nbsp; Not even close.</p>



<p>With Republicans in Congress, we&#8217;re also racing to pass the largest tax cuts in American history.&nbsp; We&#8217;re looking to &#8212; we brought it down from 41 percent &#8212; much higher, if you add the state things &#8212; but 41 percent to 21 percent, which people said was impossible.&nbsp; And now I&#8217;m trying to bring it down to 15 percent.</p>



<p>So, it&#8217;ll go from 21 to 15, but only if you make your product in the United States of America.&nbsp; Otherwise, you pay 21 percent.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; That would be great.</p>



<p>To protect American auto workers, which &#8212; who, by the way, they&#8217;re going to be one of the biggest beneficiaries of what we&#8217;re doing with tariffs &#8212; because they just stopped two big auto plants in the middle of construction from being built in Mexico because they see &#8212; when I got elected, they saw, Oh, this is going to be a problem for us.&nbsp; Because we have big tariffs going on, and we have tariffs going on autos.</p>



<p>And they don&#8217;t have to pay any tariffs.&nbsp; There is no tariff.&nbsp; All you have to do is build your plant in the United States.&nbsp; They were building plants in Mexico, right opposite the border.&nbsp; They&#8217;re making them in Mexico.&nbsp; They&#8217;re selling them into the United States with virtually no tax.&nbsp; And they&#8217;re killing all our &#8212; Detroit &#8212; all these places are being killed.&nbsp; Now it&#8217;s the exact opposite.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And by the way, Canada was a big participant in that too.&nbsp; And I think Canada &#8212; you know, they&#8217;re going to have to pay tariffs on automobiles, lumber, and oil and gas, et cetera, et cetera.&nbsp; And they get 95 percent of their product from the United States.&nbsp; I think they have to become the 51st state.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And you heard the people booing the national anthem, but I think, ultimately, they&#8217;ll be praising the national anthem.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll have to work out some deal &#8212; because I do like the O Canada.&nbsp; Right?&nbsp; It&#8217;s a beautiful thing.&nbsp; I think we&#8217;re going to have to keep it for the 51st state.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I call him Governor Trudeau.&nbsp; I said, Governor Trudeau is doing a wonderful job.&nbsp; I think it&#8217;s actually cost him his election, if you want to know the truth.</p>



<p>But we&#8217;re going to &#8212; we&#8217;re going to see about that.&nbsp; We&#8217;re looking at Greenland, and we have to take back the Panama Canal, because that wasn&#8217;t the deal.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>We gave the Panama Canal to Panama.&nbsp; It was the most expensive thing ever built in our country.&nbsp; It would be the equivalent of $2 trillion today.&nbsp; We spent massive amounts.&nbsp; We lost 38,000 lives from the mosquito and snakes.&nbsp; A lot of bad snake bites, but mostly the mosquitoes.&nbsp; They &#8212; malaria &#8212; they killed 38,000 of our people.&nbsp;</p>



<p>They paid laborers five times what they were getting in the United States to go, knowing that there was a good chance they were going to die.&nbsp; Twenty percent of them died.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And Jimmy Carter, may he rest in peace &#8212; the late, great Jimmy Carter &#8212; gave it away for $1.&nbsp;</p>



<p>It&#8217;s also the most profitable thing ever built.&nbsp; You know, it&#8217;s &#8212; what you hear about casinos and you hear about all this stuff &#8212; theyre peanuts compared to this.&nbsp; It&#8217;s very &#8212; it&#8217;s the most profitable thing ever built.&nbsp;</p>



<p>There&#8217;s never been anything &#8212; I mean, you have ships lined up.&nbsp; And by the way, when they gave it away &#8212; they gave it away like a bunch of dummies for $1.&nbsp; The day after they took over, they raised the price per ship by four times.&nbsp; That wasn&#8217;t high enough.&nbsp; There was no &#8212; no problem.&nbsp; They raised it again twice.&nbsp; And they&#8217;re getting almost a million dollars a ship.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And their product is water.&nbsp; It&#8217;s Pacific and Atlantic, where they meet.&nbsp; And one is about 18 feet higher than the other, which a lot of people don&#8217;t know. &nbsp;Actually, it&#8217;s one of the great marvels of the world.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Well, we built it.&nbsp; And we&#8217;re not going to let &#8212; because China has essentially taken it over.&nbsp; We&#8217;re not going to let that happen.&nbsp; China knows it, and so does Panama.&nbsp;</p>



<p>To protect American workers and bring billions of dollars into our treasury, we&#8217;re in the process of imposing reciprocal tariffs on any nation that tries to cheat us or steal our jobs.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, India, as an example, has very, very high tariffs, and I was going to impose a flat tariff, but that wouldn&#8217;t really do the trick, because some of the countries have really high tariffs.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, it really works out much better.&nbsp; Nobody can even fight it.&nbsp; Whatever they charge us, we charge them.&nbsp; So, if they&#8217;re at 25 percent, we are 25.&nbsp; If they&#8217;re at 75, were at &#8212;</p>



<p>Whatever they charge us &#8212; and it was very interesting.&nbsp; The European Union &#8212; you know, we were at 2.5 percent for cars.&nbsp; European Union was much higher.&nbsp; They just reduced their tariffs on cars to 2.5 to be reciprocal with ours.&nbsp; So, that&#8217;s just an early sign.&nbsp; But I think that&#8217;s going to happen.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And then some will &#8212; some will want to fight us a little bit, but it doesn&#8217;t matter.&nbsp; They&#8217;re reciprocal.&nbsp; And even the press says, Oh, I see.&nbsp; Well, they don&#8217;t fight us.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, if I put a flat tariff on, like, 25, 30 percent, even if it was lower than we would have gotten, if we put a flat tariff on, the press would have gone crazy.&nbsp; We &#8212; that&#8217;s terrible.&nbsp; Even if somebody was paying, like, five times more, charging us five times more.</p>



<p>When you say reciprocal &#8212; I said it the other day to the failing New York Times.&nbsp; I said, Listen, whatever they charge us, we charge them.&nbsp; They go, Well, that sounds fair.&nbsp; It truly does, doesn&#8217;t it?&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>So, it&#8217;s a reciprocal tariff.&nbsp; Whatever they charge us.</p>



<p>I&#8217;ve ended Joe Biden&#8217;s weaponization of our government and removed his handpicked radical-left, Marxist prosecutors from the Department of Justice.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; We have a great attorney general: Pam.</p>



<p>I immediately halted all government censorship and brought back free speech in America.&nbsp; I signed an executive order to end all of the lawless diversity, equity, and inclusion policies across the entire federal government and private sector.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Do you see how much it costs?&nbsp; One company said they&#8217;re going out of that business and they&#8217;re going to write off $229 million.&nbsp; The &#8212; how do you spend that much money to convince people that they should have transgender operations and various and sundry other things that we don&#8217;t like to talk about?&nbsp;</p>



<p>It&#8217;s crazy the amount of money that was &#8212; it was almost like a &#8212; just a mind-blower what they were doing.&nbsp; It was terrible and all over.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And by the way, our military is now free of that.&nbsp; Anybody that even tries it, they&#8217;re gone.&nbsp; I signed really historic orders to get critical race theory and transgender ideology out of the schools and out of our military.&nbsp; It&#8217;s all going out.&nbsp; It&#8217;s no longer.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And I heard men are still playing in Maine.&nbsp; Is anybody here from Maine?&nbsp; Ah.&nbsp; Who is that?&nbsp; Is that the governor?&nbsp; (Laughs.)&nbsp; That&#8217;s &#8212; well, I hate to tell you this, but we&#8217;re not going to give them any federal money.&nbsp; They are still saying we want men to play in women&#8217;s sports, and I cannot believe that they&#8217;re doing that.&nbsp; They are &#8212; (inaudible) find out who that guy is that raised his hand.&nbsp; Maybe he&#8217;s just kidding.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>But &#8212; so, we&#8217;re not going to give them any federal funding &#8212; none whatsoever &#8212; until they clean that up.&nbsp;<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And the other one, we has &#8212; have a fight with one news organization: AP, a radical-left organization.&nbsp; Treats us all very badly.&nbsp; And they refuse to acknowledge that the Gulf &#8212; former &#8212; of Mexico is now called the Gulf of America.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we just hold them &#8212; we&#8217;re holding them &#8212; we&#8217;re holding them out of our &#8212; any news conferences.&nbsp; Now, I&#8217;m sure they&#8217;ll get sued, and maybe they&#8217;ll win.&nbsp; It doesn&#8217;t matter.&nbsp; It&#8217;s just something that we feel strongly about.</p>



<p>No, and I said we changed Mount McKinley.&nbsp; Nobody is fighting that.&nbsp; You&#8217;re allowed to do it &#8212; what we&#8217;re allowed to do.&nbsp; And most of the shoreline is &#8212; you know, 85 percent of it is on our soil, but I thought it would be appropriate.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I never understood, quite, the Gulf of Mexico when it really covers us far more.&nbsp; And I think Doug is a big believer in what we did &#8212; the Gulf of America.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we&#8217;re having a little dispute, but only one.&nbsp; But Google Maps has already changed.&nbsp; Almost everybody has already changed.&nbsp; It&#8217;s called the Gulf of America.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And earlier this month, I signed an order banning men from women&#8217;s sports.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And that&#8217;s why, when somebody wants to do that &#8212; when somebody wants to do that &#8212; and even the NCAA has already complied.&nbsp; And they have sent us a letter.&nbsp; They have fully complied with that.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I also proudly banned the use of puberty blockers, hormone injections &#8212; you believe this? &#8212; and other chemical and surgical mutilations of all minor youth.&nbsp; Do you believe you have to say that?&nbsp; I mean, it&#8217;s terrible.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Who would believe that we were talking about even these things.&nbsp; Men playing in &#8212; 10 years ago, 15 years ago, can you imagine?&nbsp; People would say, Is he crazy, talking about this?</p>



<p>And they&#8217;re still fighting us, but let them fight.&nbsp; As I said, we&#8217;re going to make universal school choice a very big, strong thing.&nbsp; School choice.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And we&#8217;re working very, very hard to send these schools and education back to the states where they can be properly run.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; In other words, this really affects the people in this room.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But you&#8217;re going to be running your schools, and who can do worse?&nbsp; Look, they rate them in the top 40.&nbsp; So, we just came out with one that we were number 40, but we were number 1 in cost per pupil.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And, I mean, I know a lot of the governors in this room.&nbsp; You run a great state, and you&#8217;ll do great with education at a much lower price &#8212; we&#8217;re going to give you whatever you need &#8212; but at a much lower price.</p>



<p>We have people in Washington, D.C., that, in all fairness, in many cases, don&#8217;t give a damn about your pupils or your students or your states.&nbsp; And they&#8217;re running everything, and they&#8217;re running it into the ground. &nbsp;</p>



<p>So, it came out we&#8217;re last in education but first in cost per pupil.&nbsp; Norway; Denmark; Sweden; I have to tell you, China; and a few others are always in the top five.&nbsp; And I really believe that 35 or 36 states and all of you are here &#8212; almost all of you here representing those states, I think you&#8217;re going to have education that&#8217;s every bit as good as Norway and Denmark and Sweden and all of them.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And then we&#8217;ll have some laggards.&nbsp; And you know who the laggards are going to be.&nbsp; You just have to look at everything else.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But in everything we do, we&#8217;re putting America first, because the Republican Party is now known as the party of common sense.&nbsp; It&#8217;s the party of common sense.&nbsp; Very important.&nbsp; I think it&#8217;s a very important phrase for you to use.&nbsp; It&#8217;s all about common sense.&nbsp; We&#8217;re conservative, and, you know, were a lot of things, but most important thing is we have to use common sense.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Thanks in part to the hard work of the people in this room, we&#8217;re forging a new political majority that is shattering and replacing Franklin Roosevelt&#8217;s New Deal coalition, which dominated American politics for nearly 100 years.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Under our leadership, the Republican Party has become the proud voice of hardworking citizens of every race, religion, color, and creed.&nbsp; We are a much bigger, much more powerful party.&nbsp; Now is the time for us all to press forward, think big, be bold, and deliver the once-in-a-lifetime reforms our citizens need and really deserve.&nbsp;</p>



<p>They&#8217;ve gone through hell for four years.&nbsp; Some of them don&#8217;t even know it.&nbsp; They&#8217;ve just been led down a path.&nbsp; They don&#8217;t even know what they&#8217;ve gone through.&nbsp;</p>



<p>As one team, we can make our borders stronger, our communities safer, our schools better, our families happier, our citizens wealthier, and our country freer, freer, freer and more exceptional than ever before.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We will work together, and we will absolutely, without question, make America great again.&nbsp;</p>



<p>God bless you all.&nbsp; And do a great job.&nbsp; And go home and watch the hockey game.&nbsp; It should be interesting.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Thank you all very much.&nbsp; Thank you very much.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Thank you.&nbsp; Thank you, Brian.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; Thank you. (Applause.)<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thanks.</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; END&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 8:25 P.M. EST</p>
</div>
</main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerHTML = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

<script id="moment-js-after">
moment.updateLocale( 'en_US', {"months":["January","February","March","April","May","June","July","August","September","October","November","December"],"monthsShort":["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"],"weekdays":["Sunday","Monday","Tuesday","Wednesday","Thursday","Friday","Saturday"],"weekdaysShort":["Sun","Mon","Tue","Wed","Thu","Fri","Sat"],"week":{"dow":0},"longDateFormat":{"LT":"g:i a","LTS":null,"L":null,"LL":"F j, Y","LLL":"F j, Y g:i a","LLLL":null}} );
</script>
<script src="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-includes/js/dist/date.min.js?ver=aaca6387d1cf924acc51" id="wp-date-js"></script>
<script id="wp-date-js-after">
wp.date.setSettings( {"l10n":{"locale":"en_US","months":["January","February","March","April","May","June","July","August","September","October","November","December"],"monthsShort":["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"],"weekdays":["Sunday","Monday","Tuesday","Wednesday","Thursday","Friday","Saturday"],"weekdaysShort":["Sun","Mon","Tue","Wed","Thu","Fri","Sat"],"meridiem":{"am":"am","pm":"pm","AM":"AM","PM":"PM"},"relative":{"future":"%s from now","past":"%s ago","s":"a second","ss":"%d seconds","m":"a minute","mm":"%d minutes","h":"an hour","hh":"%d hours","d":"a day","dd":"%d days","M":"a month","MM":"%d months","y":"a year","yy":"%d years"},"startOfWeek":0},"formats":{"time":"g:i a","date":"F j, Y","datetime":"F j, Y g:i a","datetimeAbbreviated":"M j, Y g:i a"},"timezone":{"offset":-5,"offsetFormatted":"-5","string":"America\/New_York","abbr":"EST"}} );
</script>

<script id="wp-preferences-js-after">
( function() {
				var serverData = false;
				var userId = "0";
				var persistenceLayer = wp.preferencesPersistence.__unstableCreatePersistenceLayer( serverData, userId );
				var preferencesStore = wp.preferences.store;
				wp.data.dispatch( preferencesStore ).setPersistenceLayer( persistenceLayer );
			} ) ();
</script>

<path d="M188.02 427.666V417.216L188.35 416.116V393.511L191.1 394.721L174.82 416.556L171.685 413.971H199.625V419.636H168.605V414.191L188.24 388.066H195.335V427.666H188.02Z" fill="white" />
<line x1="261.93" y1="369.881" x2="261.93" y2="446.402" stroke="white" stroke-opacity="0.4" stroke-width="2.39129" />

<div class="alignfull has-wide-width wp-block-whitehouse-topper">
	<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__inner-container">
		<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__content">
			
							<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__eyebrow">
					<a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/remarks/">Remarks<svg class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__eyebrow--icon" width="11" height="11" viewBox="0 0 11 11" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
<path d="M0.724808 1.45055C0.732563 0.940756 1.15149 0.539597 1.66097 0.554084L8.18243 0.73743C8.43709 0.74459 8.66622 0.854307 8.83047 1.02583C8.99471 1.19735 9.09441 1.43101 9.09053 1.68575C9.08278 2.19554 8.66385 2.5967 8.15436 2.58221L3.85933 2.46146L10.0157 8.89043C10.3703 9.2608 10.3618 9.84465 9.99583 10.1951C9.62987 10.5455 9.04621 10.5288 8.69154 10.1584L2.5352 3.72945L2.46984 8.02568C2.46209 8.53547 2.04316 8.93663 1.53368 8.92214C1.02419 8.90766 0.617659 8.48345 0.625575 7.97383L0.724808 1.45055Z" fill="currentColor" />
</svg>
</a>				</div>
			
							<h1 class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__headline">
					REMARKS BY PRESIDENT TRUMP<br>AT FUTURE INVESTMENT INITIATIVE INSTITUTE PRIORITY SUMMIT 				</h1>
			
			
				<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta">
					<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta--byline-subcategory">
						
<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-byline-subcategory">
	The White House</div>
					</div>
					
					<div class="wp-block-whitehouse-topper__meta--date">
						<div class="wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2025-02-19T18:10:48-05:00">February 19, 2025</time></div>					</div>
				</div>

			
					</div>
	</div>
</div>



<p class="has-text-align-center">Faena Hotel &amp; Forum</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center">Miami Beach, Florida</p>



<p class="has-text-align-center">(February 19, 2025)</p>



<p>5:35 P.M. EST</p>



<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; THE PRESIDENT:&nbsp; Thank you very much.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; What a great group this is.&nbsp; You have to see outside.&nbsp; Its going wild outside with a lot of love for all of us, I guess.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>But thank you, Richard, for the introduction.&nbsp; And thank you to all for such a warm welcome.&nbsp;</p>



<p>It&#8217;s great to be back in beautiful Miami, where Ive actually built a lot of great buildings with the Dezer family and some others.&nbsp; Weve had tremendous success in Miami.&nbsp; We have Trump Towers in Sunny Isles Beach.&nbsp; Its four beautiful buildings right on the ocean.&nbsp;</p>



<p>The Trump Grande &#8212; put the little E on the end for a little &#8212; class it up a little bit.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Trump Grande.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And the 700-acre Doral.&nbsp; Thats a tremendous country club in the &#8212; its actually the most successful country club in the U.S., where I was just given approval to build 1,500 units.</p>



<p>And I couldnt care less about building units.&nbsp; When youre president, who the hell wants to build units?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Ive been building units all my life.&nbsp; I dont want to build units, but they gave us permission to do it.</p>



<p>But today is a tremendous honor to become the first American president to address the Future Investment Initiative Institute.&nbsp; Thats the first one.&nbsp; Thats very &#8212; its always nice.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And I want to thank Mayor of Miami Francis Suarez for being here.&nbsp; Thank you very much, Francis, wherever you may be.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Hi, Francis.&nbsp; And thank you for the endorsement when I ran.&nbsp; I was very appreciative.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Along with the mayor of Miami Beach, Steven Meiner.&nbsp; Steven, thank you very much.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; Thank you, Steven.&nbsp; Thank you very much.</p>



<p>And numerous American business leaders, some of the bi- &#8212; biggest business leaders, actually, anywhere in the world, and many distinguished guests from the Middle East, and, in particular, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia &#8212; a special place with special leaders.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And including FII Institute chairman and governor of the Public Investment Fund, which is a seriously big fund, Yasir.&nbsp; I see you there.&nbsp; Stand up, Yasir.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Everyone knows Yasir. &nbsp;Thank you.&nbsp; Great guy.&nbsp; Great, great person.</p>



<p>And Finance Minister Mohammed, thank you very much.&nbsp; Thank you right &#8212; thank you very much.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Good to see you again.&nbsp; Thats pretty good: finance minister of that part of the world.&nbsp; Thats not bad.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Other parts of the world, not so good, but that one is good.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>And many other senior government leaders.&nbsp; I also want to recognize the Kingdom&#8217;s ambassador to the United States, Her Royal Highness Princess Reema.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Ooh, very popular.&nbsp; Very popular.&nbsp; Wow.&nbsp; Thats very nice.&nbsp; Sitting next to Elon.&nbsp; Wow, thats &#8212; you couldnt do better than that, huh?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>As well as my own special envoy to the Middle East, who has really done a fantastic job, Steve Witkoff.&nbsp; Thank you, Steve.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Hes been busy.&nbsp; And Michael Waltz is here.&nbsp; Where is Michael?&nbsp; Michael has been so busy.&nbsp; Theyve been going back and forth and back.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And a woman who was just voted the most powerful woman an- &#8212; anywhere in the world &#8212; (applause) &#8212; no, Ill go with &#8212; Im going to go with Princess Reema &#8212; but she was voted the most powerful woman anywhere in the world: Susie Wiles.&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you.&nbsp; Most powerful woman, thats pretty good.&nbsp; We have to talk to you about that, Susie.&nbsp; Thats pretty good.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>And also, we all know Jared Kushner, a very special guy.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you, Jared.&nbsp; Thank you, Jared.</p>



<p>And Elon Musk.&nbsp; Hes been making a little news lately, hasnt he, though?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Very positive news.&nbsp; Stand up, Elon.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Hes a great guy.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We did a little show last night.&nbsp; I heard that it got very good ratings, too, by the way.&nbsp; We did Hannity.&nbsp; Sean Hannity was fantastic &#8212; a fantastic man, a fantastic guy, and he did a show.&nbsp; And it was great being on the show with you last night.</p>



<p>I come today with a simple message for business leaders from all across the nation and all around the world: If you want to build the future, push boundaries, unleash breakthroughs, transform industries, and make a fortune &#8212; because you want to make fortune; most of you have already made a fortune, I dont want to say &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; there is no better place on Earth than the current and future United States of America under a certain president named Donald J. Trump.&nbsp; I think that youre going to do very well.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Theyre saying that November 5th &#8212; Election Day &#8212; 2024, will go down as one of the most important days in the history of our country.&nbsp; They said, In 129 years, the most consequential election.&nbsp; I dont know if theyre right about that or not, but it sounds good.&nbsp; I wanted to see if I could get a couple of more years tacked on, but I figured the fight wasnt really worth it.&nbsp; One hundred and twenty-nine is a lot.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And as of January 20th, 2025, the dark days of high taxes, crushing regulations, rampant inflation, flagrant corruption, government weaponization &#8212; ooh, I know about weaponization &#8212; and total incompetence will be gone forever.&nbsp; Will be gone forever.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Because the United States is back and open for business, and the golden age of America has officially begun.&nbsp; You see it happening.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Since my election, America&#8217;s economic engines have come roaring back to life in just a very short period of time.&nbsp; Think of it.&nbsp; From November 5th, the &#8212; the progress thats been made has been amazing.&nbsp; The Nasdaq is up nearly 10 percent in just a few months, and thats a lot.&nbsp; The Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 2,200 points.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And Bitcoin has set multiple all-time record highs, because everyone knows that Im committed to making America the crypto capital.&nbsp; We want to stay &#8212; we want to stay at the forefront of everything, and one of them is crypto.&nbsp; And Miami seems to be the center of the action, come to think of it, and maybe itll stay there.</p>



<p>Business optimism skyrocketed 42 points &#8212; think of that &#8212; in a single month.&nbsp; The most in history, by far.&nbsp; Thats the biggest increase in history by not even close.&nbsp;</p>



<p>The ISM index of manufacturing activity surged into positive territory for the first time in many years.&nbsp; Amazing.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And it was just announced &#8212; this is an interesting one.&nbsp; I didnt realize it was that bad for so long.&nbsp; But it was just announced by one of the nation&#8217;s most historically accurate and respected pollsters, Rasmussen, that the number of Americans who believe our country is on the right track now exceeds those who think it&#8217;s heading in the wrong direction for the first time in 20 years.&nbsp; Can you believe you that?&nbsp; Twenty years.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And this is really a seismic 27-point swing from just before the election.&nbsp; Thats &#8212; nobody has ever seen anything like that one, Yasir.&nbsp; I want to tell you.&nbsp; Thats a big one.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>The best and most successful business leaders on Earth are now racing to invest in the United States.&nbsp; Since November, DAMAC has announced plans to invest $40 billion in the U.S., creating at least 10,000 jobs.&nbsp; SoftBank has announced investments of between $100- and $200 billion, creating at least 100,000 American jobs.&nbsp; Oracle and OpenAI and SoftBank are now collectively committing $500 billion to keep the United States on the cutting edge of artificial intelligence.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And so many more &#8212; I mean, so many companies, they want to come to the White House and have a little news conference all the time.&nbsp; I said, Why dont you just announce it?&nbsp; But they want to come, and Ill do that.&nbsp; I dont mind doing that.&nbsp; I say anytime they want to go $10 billion or more, Im &#8212; Im there.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp; Ten billion or more.</p>



<p>But on his recent visit to the White House, the prime minister of Japan announced he anticipates Japanese investment in the United States of well over a trillion dollars, and were working on an Alaska pipeline already, which is the closest point to Asia.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And as you know, the ANWR, which weve started, Ronald Reagan couldnt get it approved.&nbsp; Nobody could get it approved for so many years.&nbsp; Couldnt get it approved.&nbsp; I got it approved.&nbsp; Actually, I got it approved twice.&nbsp; I got it approved, and Biden ended it.&nbsp; That was a shocker.&nbsp; But we just got it approved again.&nbsp; And were going to be &#8212; (applause) &#8212; its &#8212; its probably the largest deposit maybe anywhere in the world, just by itself.&nbsp; Its &#8212; they say of similar size to Saudi Arabia, so we hope thats correct.</p>



<p>But all of this is only happening because of the world-changing results of the 2024 election.&nbsp; We won the House.&nbsp; We won the Senate, the White House, and the Electoral College and the popular vote in a landslide.&nbsp; We also won all seven swing states, and all 50 states shifted in the Republican direction for the first time ever.&nbsp; So, every state &#8212; every single state of the 50 states shifted Republican.&nbsp; Thats never happened before.&nbsp; Either way, its never happened.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And 85 percent of counties voted for Trump.&nbsp; Think of that.&nbsp; So, you have 2,600 counties versus 525.&nbsp; Two thousand six hundred, think of that.&nbsp; Thats why when you look at the election map, after it was all done &#8212; the certified map &#8212; the whole thing was red &#8212; 2,600 versus 500.&nbsp; It&#8217;s a big, big dif- &#8212; nobody&#8217;s seen anything like it, actually.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, as a result of this very historic victory, investors from all over the planet, once again, have confidence in America&#8217;s future and respect for America&#8217;s leaders, and it&#8217;s about time we get a little respect.&nbsp;</p>



<p>The last administration was the worst and most incompetent in the history of our country, but we are moving quickly to fix every single disaster Joe Biden created and make America stronger and more prosperous than ever before.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>Our first and most urgent mission is to remove the criminals that Biden allowed into our country with the ridiculous and very dangerous open-borders policy.&nbsp; They came from all over the world.&nbsp; They came from prisons and jails.&nbsp; They came from mental institutions and insane asylums.&nbsp; They were gang members.&nbsp; They were drug lords.&nbsp; They came from all over, and they were allowed to come into our country.&nbsp; And we&#8217;re getting them out in record levels, just like they came in in record levels.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I want to thank Tom Homan and Kristi, who is just doing &#8212; she&#8217;s doing a fantastic job &#8212; governor of South Dakota &#8212; and Tom Homan, you know, and they are doing a fantastic job.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; And the results are incredible.</p>



<p>And every country is taking them back.&nbsp; They&#8217;re sending their criminals to us, and they&#8217;re all taking them back.&nbsp; We had a little problem with a couple of them.&nbsp; That ended very quickly.&nbsp; And because some said, We don&#8217;t really want MS-13 back in our country.&nbsp; But I said, Congratulations, you&#8217;re taking them back, and they take them back.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And, by the way, Europe and other places ought to start also doing that.&nbsp; They better start looking at immigration, because it&#8217;s really hurting Europe very, very badly.&nbsp; And they better get smart and they better get tough before it&#8217;s too late.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We&#8217;re also working to end the highest inflation in our country&#8217;s history, all caused because they played with our energy policy and wasted money on the <a>Green New Scam </a>and other things such as that, and they wasted monies at &#8212; at never-seen-before levels.&nbsp; If Joe Biden had simply held federal spending at the pre-pandemic levels we had in 2019, we &#8212; right now, we would have virtually no inflation.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We&#8217;re trying to balance the budget immediately, and because of the tariff income, which is really go- &#8212; its &#8212; it&#8217;s already turned out to be amazing, actually.&nbsp; It&#8217;s really meant more for bringing countries and companies into our country, but it&#8217;s &#8212; the numbers are rather staggering, because we&#8217;re the big piggy bank that everybody wants to be.&nbsp; And they can play games, and they can say, Well, there&#8217;ll be retribution and, you know, equal this and that, but they can&#8217;t be equal.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we want to keep it so that we&#8217;re the big piggy bank.&nbsp; And if we had years like we did the last four years, that wouldn&#8217;t have lasted too long.&nbsp; So, we&#8217;re not promising it, but you know, all of these things could happen.&nbsp; We &#8212; we hope to balance our budget.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, I don&#8217;t want to promise it, because if I do and we come about $10 short, the fake news media back there would say, We have breaking news.&nbsp; He did not make it.&nbsp; He did not make it.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we&#8217;ll get it done very soon.&nbsp; It might not be this year, but it could be this year.&nbsp; Actually, we have a chance at getting it even this year, which people would be shocked at, because they were talking about 10 years, 15 years, 20 years from now.</p>



<p>When I took office last month, we inherited the consequences of inflation that was more than four times what it was when I left four years ago.&nbsp; Think of that, I left, it was at 1.4 percent.&nbsp; And the annual government spending over $1.5 trillion more than projected in 2020 alone &#8212; $1.5 trillion.</p>



<p>But under the Trump administration, all of that is changing faster and more dramatically than anyone ever thought possible.&nbsp; They didn&#8217;t think it was possible to do what we&#8217;ve done in just a very short period of time.&nbsp; We&#8217;ve accomplished more in four weeks than most administrations accomplish in four years.&nbsp;</p>



<p>On my first day in office, I imposed an immediate federal hiring freeze, a federal regulation freeze, and a foreign aid freeze.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I signed an order creating the Department of Government Efficiency and put a man named Elon Musk in charge.&nbsp; Thank you, Elon, for doing it.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Thank you very much.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And he&#8217;s doing a great job.&nbsp; I wish you could have seen him last night.&nbsp; It&#8217;s really &#8212; you know, he&#8217;s a very committed person.&nbsp; He&#8217;s a very serious person.&nbsp; And he&#8217;s a very high-IQ people.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You know, I like high-IQ people.&nbsp; Not all have to be, but, you know, itd be nice to have some people up there that &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; he&#8217;s a seriously high-IQ individual.&nbsp; Now, he&#8217;s got his faults also, I will tell you that &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; but not too many of them.</p>



<p>Which is now really waging war on government waste, fraud, and abuse, and they&#8217;re curbing inflation and saving taxpayers billions and billions of dollars every single day.&nbsp; And there&#8217;s even under consideration a new concept where we give 20 percent of the DOGE savings to American citizens and 20 percent goes to paying down debt, because the numbers are incredible, Elon.&nbsp; So many billions of dollars &#8212; its billions &#8212; hundreds of billions, and we&#8217;re thinking about giving 20 percent back to the American citizens and 20 percent down to pay back debt &#8212; and pay down debt, which is &#8212; if you look at value, if it were a real estate balance sheet, the debt is tiny, but we still &#8212; we still want to pay it down.&nbsp; Doesn&#8217;t matter.&nbsp; We don&#8217;t look at it as a piece of real estate.&nbsp; It&#8217;s America.&nbsp; We&#8217;re going to get it down through intelligence, hard work, and, as Elon said, a word called caring.&nbsp; You have to have &#8212; you have to care.&nbsp;</p>



<p>By doing this, Americans will tell us where there is waste.&nbsp; They&#8217;ll be reporting it themselves.&nbsp; They participate in the process of saving money.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So many of the men and women in this room, as an example, they pay tremendous amounts of taxes.&nbsp; And here are just a few examples of where your money was going before I came along.&nbsp; These are just some of the &#8212; just taken at random.&nbsp; Oh, there are much worse examples than this.&nbsp; I was just looking at them before the speech, and I can tell you there were much worse.&nbsp; And there are some that are horrible, but I don&#8217;t want to really say them, because they&#8217;re very, very embarrassing to people &#8212; very, very embarrassing.&nbsp; And they&#8217;re really something, but you&#8217;ll be seeing it and you will be reading about it.</p>



<p>But just some taking at random:</p>



<p>$2 million for sex change operations in Guatemala.</p>



<p>$20 million for Sesame Street performances in Iraq.&nbsp; Twenty million, that&#8217;s a lot of money.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; You know, I know what it costs to do those things.&nbsp; You get a cast over for $50,000, give them a couple of bucks tip.&nbsp; That&#8217;s it.&nbsp; Not $20 million.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Twenty million, that&#8217;s Gone With the Wind on steroids.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>$101 million for 29 diversity, equity, and inclusion contracts at the Department of Education.&nbsp; Wow.</p>



<p>And we&#8217;ve also canceled &#8212; we&#8217;ve canceled all of these, saved all of this money.&nbsp; And, again, this is just a small sample.&nbsp; This could go on.&nbsp; I could read them all day.&nbsp;</p>



<p>$520 million for a consultant &#8212; I want to know who is that consultant &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; to do ESG &#8212; that&#8217;s environmental, social, and governance &#8212; investments in Africa.&nbsp;</p>



<p>$25 million to promote biodiversity conservation and licit livelihoods by developing socially responsible behavior in Colombia.&nbsp;</p>



<p>$40 million to improve the social and economic inclusion of sedentary migrants.&nbsp; Nobody knows what that even means.&nbsp; None of this stuff.&nbsp; Nobody.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Everyone is trying to figure out, What the hell does it all mean?</p>



<p>$42 million for social and behavior changes in Uganda.&nbsp; Forty million is a lot of newspaper ads in Uganda.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>$70 million for research of evidence-based solutions for development challenges.</p>



<p>$10 million for Mozambique medical male circumcision.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; What does that &#8212; what does that mean?</p>



<p>$2.3 million dollars for strengthening independent voices in Cambodia.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>$14 million for improving public procurement in Serbia.</p>



<p>$486 million to the Consortium for Elections and Political Process Strengthening, including $22 million for inclusion &#8212; inclusive and participatory political process in Moldova and $21 million for voter turnout in India.&nbsp; What do we need to spend $21 million for voter turnout in India?&nbsp; Wow, $21 million.&nbsp; I guess they were trying to get somebody else elected.&nbsp; Wow, we ought to tell the Indian government, because when we hear that Russia spent about two dollars in our country, it was a big deal.&nbsp; Right?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; They took &#8212; they took some Internet ads for $2,000.&nbsp; This is a total breakthrough: twenty-one million dollars for India elections.</p>



<p>$29 million to strengthen the political landscape in Bangladesh.</p>



<p><a>$20 million for fiscal federalism, and $19 million in addition to the $21 million, for biodiversity <s>conversion</s> [conservation] in Nepal.</a></p>



<p>$1.5 million for voter confidence in Liberia.&nbsp; We need voter confidence too, when you read this list.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>$14 million for social cohesion in Mali.</p>



<p>$2.5 million for inclusive democracies in South Africa.</p>



<p>$47 million for improving learning outcomes in Asia.&nbsp; Asia is doing very well.&nbsp; We dont need to give them money.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>And in another program, $50 million, plus another $50 million, for condoms for Hamas.&nbsp; You know about that?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; A hundred million dollars for condoms.&nbsp; Condoms.&nbsp; Does everybody know what a condom is?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; For Hamas &#8212; $100 million.&nbsp;</p>



<p><a>And these are just some.&nbsp; I could read this list all day long.&nbsp; I just dont want to bore you.&nbsp; But these are just some, and not nearly as bad as others.&nbsp; And some are just &#8212; I just dont want to say them because theyre too &#8212; theyre too <s>incenduary</s> [incendiary].</a></p>



<p>Were also finding tremendous abuse, waste, and fraud in Social Security.&nbsp; Social Security is &#8212; whats happening there is going to be one of the great potential scandals in history.&nbsp;</p>



<p>On the program, there are over 4.7 million Social Security numbers from people from 100 years old to 109.&nbsp; Think of that.&nbsp; Now, over 100, there arent a lot of people that make it.&nbsp; Hopefully most of the people in this room will make it, but historically, you dont have thousands and thousands of people.&nbsp; But listen to this: 3.6 million people are on Social Security rolls from the age of 110 years old to 119.&nbsp; Do you think there are really that many?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Those people are seriously old.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; But it gets worse.&nbsp;</p>



<p>3.47 million &#8212; 3.47 million people are on Social Security from the age of 120 years old to 129 years old.&nbsp;</p>



<p>3.9 million people are on the age of Social Security from 130 years old to 139 years old.&nbsp; Now the all-time record, I heard, is a woman who was a hundred &#8212; she was 127 years old.&nbsp; Thats the record.&nbsp; A woman from a certain country where they have actually people that live pretty long, actually.&nbsp; And she was 127 years old.&nbsp; Thats pretty old, but were topping her by millions &#8212; millions of people.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>3.5 million people from the age 140 to 149 years old.&nbsp;</p>



<p>1.3 million people are on Social Security from the age 150 to 159.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And over 130,000 people are on Social Security over the age of 160 years old &#8212; okay? &#8212; including 1,039 people &#8212; think of it &#8212; over 1,000 people &#8212; between the ages of 220 to 229.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; And one person between the age of 240 to 249.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And the record-topper: There is one person on Social Security who is 360 years old &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; which is approximately 110 years older than our country.&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p><a>So, what were trying to find out and what we will find out is are people being paid from all of these.&nbsp; You know, is somebody pocketing $10,000 here, $10,000 there?&nbsp; Whats going on?&nbsp; So, well find that out pretty easily because we have a lot of computer geniuses.</a></p>



<p>I said to Elon, Who are these people that are doing this, the DOGE people?&nbsp; I said, Who are they?&nbsp; Where do they come from?&nbsp; He said, Well, number one, they love our country, and, number two, theyre really genius at computers.&nbsp; So, nobody is going to fool them.&nbsp; When they go in, they see some bureaucrat thats scamming the country, and they try and talk about, you know, certain computer language, these people say, No, it doesnt work that way.&nbsp; These are people that are &#8212; have a natural ability as &#8212; as, you know, brilliant computer people.</p>



<p>It was very interesting when he told me that.&nbsp; I said, Thats what you need today.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But all of these scams have now been terminated.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In addition, over the past month, we have effectively eliminated the U.S. Agency for International Development, which was funding much of this lunacy.&nbsp; We virtually shut down the out-of-control CFPB, escorting radical-left bureaucrats out of the building and locking the doors behind them.&nbsp; What they were doing was so terrible.&nbsp; Where they were spending the money was so terrible.&nbsp;</p>



<p>What we havent looked at yet but will be is does the money come back to them, because nobody can be stupid like that.&nbsp; And theyre not stupid.&nbsp; Theyre smart, actually.&nbsp; And, you know, why are doing that?&nbsp; Does money come back to them?&nbsp; So, well figure that out pretty easily, I think, and quickly.</p>



<p>But Ive ended all of the so-called diversity, equity, and inclusion programs across the entire federal government and private sector and notified every single government DEI officer that their jobs have been deleted.&nbsp; Theyre all deleted.&nbsp; And its interesting, even these country &#8212; these companies that have tremendous &#8212; the amounts of money &#8212; a number of them just announced &#8212; Walmart, if you can believe it, they just announced that theyre stopping.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And, you know, these companies are writing off, like, $220 million.&nbsp; How can you spend that much money no matter what youre doing?&nbsp; If youre teaching something, youre going to have an instructor, youre going to talk, youre going to give them a book, Please read the book.&nbsp; You know, and then you find they spent $225 million on that.&nbsp; Whats going on?</p>



<p>And we were going in the wrong way, and our military was really &#8212; although, I tell you, you know, we &#8212; we defeated ISIS with our military in three weeks.&nbsp; General Razin Caine was &#8212; hes some general.&nbsp; Hes a real general, not a television general.&nbsp; And three weeks &#8212; ISIS.&nbsp; And I &#8212; I asked him, and I saw some of his people that were so great, the soldiers.&nbsp; We have the greatest military in the world, but we dont have the greatest top, top leadership.&nbsp; Thats why Afghanistan was such a horrible situation and so embarrassing and so many other things.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But when we want to, with proper leadership, theres nobody even close to us.&nbsp; We have the best equipment in the world.&nbsp; We make the best equipment in the world.&nbsp; But we have the best military, but, you know, we never fight to win.&nbsp; We fight to just keep it going forever.&nbsp; And when we fight to win, theres nobody that can even come close to us.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But I was talking to General Dan Caine, and we call him Razin Caine.&nbsp; And I was told it would take about four years to defeat ISIS, and he did it in three weeks.&nbsp; I said to him, What do you think, General?&nbsp; How long will it take?&nbsp; Sir, I think we should do it in less than four weeks.&nbsp; Youre going to have time leftover.&nbsp; And he did.&nbsp; He did that.&nbsp; And we were told by the television generals it would take four years.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we did it.&nbsp; Thats when I went to Iraq.&nbsp; I flew to Iraq and &#8212; late at night &#8212; the dark of night, all the windows closed, all the lights off in the plane, in Air Force One.&nbsp; And we flew in, and it was pretty amazing.&nbsp; Ill tell you, we were landing, and there were no lights.&nbsp; No lights on the plane.&nbsp; Sir, we have to turn off all lights.&nbsp; I said, You mean we spend $9 trillion, and we have to fly in on Air Force One with the lights off?&nbsp; And I went up to the pilot and said hello.</p>



<p>And, by the way, these guys are like central casting.&nbsp; These are the best-looking human beings.&nbsp; Everybody is, like, perfect.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; The most handsome people, the best-looking people youve ever seen, with the flattops and the whole thing.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And I was a little concerned because the lights are off, and everything is off, and even the lights in where he was were down very dim &#8212; very, very dim with all of the lights on the fancy dashboards of the plane of Air Force One.</p>



<p>Were getting a new Air Force One if they can ever finish the damn thing.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Were getting two of them, actually.&nbsp; But we may have to go a different route because its taking them a long time.&nbsp; Were going to get military thats going to start building.&nbsp; Were going to get people to start building properly again in our country, because they dont build properly.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; This was Boeing.</p>



<p>But were &#8212; we&#8217;re up there, and I&#8217;m looking at these people.&nbsp; And, again, cent- &#8212; I say they look like Tom Cruise but better &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; stronger, tougher.&nbsp; And I like Tom Cruise, but these are better.&nbsp; And I said &#8212; I said, Are we okay, Captain?&nbsp; Yes, sir, we&#8217;re fine.&nbsp; But I&#8217;m looking out.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t see any lights, and we&#8217;re landing. And Im &#8212; you know, I&#8217;m used to that.&nbsp; I like to sit with the pilots a lot, and I respect the pilots greatly.</p>



<p>And we&#8217;re up there, and, you know, we have the computer &#8212; I call it the computer voice, where it goes 1,000, 900, 800.&nbsp; Thats feet &#8212; your feet above ground.&nbsp; So, that means you&#8217;re very low.&nbsp; And I&#8217;m looking out, and my eyes are pretty good, and I don&#8217;t see any lights.&nbsp; And the computer goes out.&nbsp; It sounds like a &#8212; an intelligent individual.&nbsp; It goes, 1,000.&nbsp; Were a thousand feet up.&nbsp; That&#8217;s very &#8212; it&#8217;s a 10-story building.&nbsp; This is a big, big plane.&nbsp; And then it goes, 900, 800, 700.&nbsp; I say, Captain.&nbsp; (Clears throat.)&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; Captain, we don&#8217;t see any lights.&nbsp; I said, Is everything &#8212; Yes, sir.&nbsp; Everything is fine, sir.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll be landing in three minutes.</p>



<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; And then it goes, like, 600, 500.&nbsp; Captain, are we okay?&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; And then it goes, 400, 300, 200.&nbsp; And I&#8217;m saying, Man, there&#8217;s nothing out there.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>And then he goes boom.&nbsp; Perfect landing, right on this thing.&nbsp; There are no lights on the runway.&nbsp; There&#8217;s no n- &#8212; I don&#8217;t know how the hell they do it, but I&#8217;m sure as hell glad we had somebody that knows how to fly.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>But they didn&#8217;t want to have any lights because they didn&#8217;t want the enemy &#8212; after spending, you know, years and trillions of dollars, we have to land with Air Force One with no lights on the runway.&nbsp; But they were incredible people.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And then I got out of the plane, and I actually asked my people &#8212; you know, I said, Excuse me, I was very brave sitting in that cockpit.&nbsp; Am I allowed to give myself the Congressional Medal of Honor?&nbsp; (Laughter and applause.)&nbsp; And they said, I don&#8217;t think so, sir.&nbsp; I said, Well, I felt I was extremely brave.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>But now here&#8217;s the problem with saying a story like that.&nbsp; When you kid, the press will say, President Donald Trump wanted to give himself the Congressional Medal of Honor.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp;&nbsp; Headlines, you know?&nbsp; Headlines all over the fake news.&nbsp; We call it the fake news, but we&#8217;re all wise to them.</p>



<p>But it was something.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And then I went down, and it was the same thing.&nbsp; I&#8217;m standing on the top, and I look down and there&#8217;s these handsome people.&nbsp; Everybody is like from a movie set.&nbsp; Good-looking guys.&nbsp; I get down the stairs, and What&#8217;s your name?&nbsp; My name is Caine, sir.&nbsp; What&#8217;s your first name?&nbsp; They call me Razin.&nbsp; I say, Wait a minute.&nbsp; Your name is Razin Caine?&nbsp; I love you.&nbsp; I&#8217;ve been looking for you for five years.&nbsp; You are the grea- &#8212; (laughter) &#8212; This is what I want.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And there was a general next to him.&nbsp; There was a colonel.&nbsp; There was a drill sergeant, a master sergeant.&nbsp; They were all, like, people &#8212; I could make a movie right now.&nbsp; I&#8217;d have the best-looking people ever.&nbsp; And they were great.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And then I went in, and Sir, would you like to rest before the me- &#8212; No, I don&#8217;t want to rest.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t want to rest.&nbsp; I&#8217;ve been resting on the plane, other than the last few moments, which were quite harrowing.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; And I said, I don&#8217;t want to rest.&nbsp; He was thinking about Biden in advance, you know?&nbsp; Biden would have gone there; he would have rested for days.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; They &#8212; and then they wouldn&#8217;t have had a meeting.&nbsp; Hed just go home.&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>No, I said, I don&#8217;t want to rest.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t want to rest at all.&nbsp; I want to go.</p>



<p>So, we went into this, like, bunker, and we had a lot of very good, talented people.&nbsp; And that&#8217;s when I asked him.&nbsp; I said, You know, I&#8217;m hearing it&#8217;s going to take a long time.&nbsp; No, that&#8217;s not right, sir.&nbsp; It&#8217;s not going to take a long time.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll have it done in four weeks.&nbsp; I said, How can you say four weeks when, in Washington, they said four years?&nbsp; He said, Its four weeks, sir.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll hit them left.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll hit them right.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll hit them up the center.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll hit them underground and overground.&nbsp; We&#8217;ll knock the hell out of them, sir.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And I said, Why is it that they said so long?&nbsp; He said, Because they wouldn&#8217;t let us fight, and we&#8217;re very far away.&nbsp; They want us to fight for this &#8212; from this airport.&nbsp; We&#8217;re very, very far away, sir, and they want us to fight here.&nbsp; We have many substations out &#8212; sub-airports, they call them.&nbsp; Remote airports, where they build them in the sand.&nbsp; And we have many of them, and I&#8217;d use them all, sir, and I would hit them so hard from so many different directions.</p>



<p>I said, Well, what do you think?&nbsp; He said, You just let me know.&nbsp; And I called him back, and I said, Go ahead and do it.&nbsp; Are you sure you can do this, General?&nbsp; He said, Yes, sir.&nbsp; And he did it, actually, in three weeks.&nbsp; It was over.&nbsp; A hundred percent of people that are really hurting the Middle East, hurting the world &#8212; and it was done.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And we have &#8212; I&#8217;m telling you, we have the greatest military in the world, but you have to use the right people.&nbsp; But there&#8217;s nothing like what they were able to do in that case.&nbsp; And in other cases, wherever I gave them something, it was done incredibly well and very &#8212; and you know many of the instances, because it&#8217;s been well reported.</p>



<p>But we&#8217;ve also required &#8212; and we ha- &#8212; so, we have a country that&#8217;s a great country.&nbsp; It&#8217;s a strong country, but it&#8217;s a country that&#8217;s just now gaining its respect back to the levels that it should &#8212; should have never lost.&nbsp; We were being laughed at by the entire world, but we&#8217;re not being laughed at anymore.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we&#8217;ve also required that all federal employees must once again show up to work.&nbsp; This is a new phenomenon, you know, since COVID.&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp; Show up to work in person like the rest of us.&nbsp; So, I mean, it doesn&#8217;t work when you don&#8217;t show up.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And I see companies now are all going back to it.&nbsp; They&#8217;re all going back.&nbsp; It&#8217;s great.&nbsp; I want some of the big business leaders saying, We absolutely are going back.&nbsp; You &#8212; you j- &#8212; you can&#8217;t work at home.&nbsp; They&#8217;re not working.&nbsp; They&#8217;re playing tennis, they&#8217;re playing golf, or they have other jobs, but they&#8217;re not working &#8212; or they&#8217;re certainly not working hard.&nbsp; You could never build a company or a country with that.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, we have a very strong policy.&nbsp; And if they don&#8217;t show up to work, they &#8212; they get fired.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And were trying to make our government smaller but much stronger.&nbsp; And we have tremendous bureaucracy, but it&#8217;s happening.&nbsp; A lot of people are leaving and, in some cases, leaving with pretty good offers.&nbsp; You know, you&#8217;re paid seven or eight months and go out, find a job.&nbsp; But some of these people had jobs.&nbsp; They were actually working for us, but they also had other jobs.&nbsp; And those people, in theory, they have problems.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t know if we&#8217;re going to do anything about that.&nbsp; So, we have other things to do, but they were working other jobs instead of working for us.&nbsp; So, they were staying home working, but they were working other jobs, getting paid a lot of money, perhaps.&nbsp;</p>



<p>We offered deferred resignation buyouts to all federal workers, resulting in more than 75,000 bureaucrats voluntarily surrendering their taxpayer-funded jobs.&nbsp; A lot of them are leaving because they don&#8217;t want to be caught having the second job, some are leaving because they didn&#8217;t want to be in government any longer, and &#8212; and some are leaving because they didn&#8217;t want to show up to work.&nbsp; They wanted to work outside of an office, and that&#8217;s never going to work for anybody, including companies.&nbsp; The companies ought to get smart.&nbsp;</p>



<p>You watch these companies where they do that: They start going bad.&nbsp; Nobody knows &#8212; what&#8217;s wrong with this company?&nbsp; Well, try getting the people back into the office where they can be cohesive and together.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In less than a single month, the Department of Government Efficiency has already saved over 55- &#8212; this is just a short period of time &#8212; $55 billion, and we&#8217;re just getting started.&nbsp; That&#8217;s nothing compared to the numbers that you&#8217;re talking about, right?&nbsp; (Applause.)&nbsp;</p>



<p>We&#8217;re ending trillions of dollars in waste, and it&#8217;ll mean much lower inflation; lower interest rates; lower payments on mortgages, credit cards, car loans; and much higher stock markets.&nbsp; I think the stock market is going to be great.&nbsp; In other words, we will rapidly grow our economy by dramatically shrinking the federal government, and we have to do it.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I&#8217;m also taking fast action to end the radical lefts nation-wrecking crusade against oil and natural gas.&nbsp; Over the past four years, the Biden administration cut the number of new oil leases and gas leases by 95 percent.&nbsp; They slowed new pipeline.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I mean, look at the &#8212; any one.&nbsp; Dakota Access, they wanted that one knocked out.&nbsp; The Keystone Pipeline, they wanted that one knocked out.&nbsp; They ended the Keystone.&nbsp; We got the Dakota Access done, but it wasn&#8217;t easy after they tried to stop it.</p>



<p>They slowed new oil and gas pipeline construction to virtually a halt.&nbsp; They shut down 38 percent of active oil and gas rigs in the United States.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But they love the wind turbines.&nbsp; They go round and round and round.&nbsp; And if the wind doesn&#8217;t blow, they got problems.&nbsp; They kill all the birds.&nbsp; They ruin the sight lines.&nbsp; <a>They ruin the plains and the beautiful areas of our country</a>, including the oceans, the lakes.&nbsp;</p>



<p>They closed more than 50 power plants, all causing energy prices to skyrocket.&nbsp; You saw that happen.&nbsp; That&#8217;s what caused the inflation.&nbsp; Its pretty easy.&nbsp;</p>



<p>These policies were so destructive that despite draining nearly 40 percent of U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve meant for emergencies &#8212; it was meant for emergencies.&nbsp; It wasn&#8217;t meant for getting the price of gasoline down so that you can win an election.&nbsp; Didn&#8217;t work for winning the election.&nbsp; Actually, there&#8217;s so many people that are driving that it&#8217;s a very small number.&nbsp; It just had a very small effect.&nbsp; But in the meantime, it takes it down.&nbsp; Its at &#8212; now it&#8217;s at the lo- &#8212; we&#8217;ll fill it up fast, but it&#8217;s at the lowest level.&nbsp;</p>



<p>When we made the transition, it was at the lowest level in history ever recorded.&nbsp; Its the lowest level.&nbsp; Nobody&#8217;s ever seen it that way.&nbsp; They &#8212; they put it all out because they thought they could keep gasoline prices down a little bit.&nbsp; Just go past the election, and then after that, they didn&#8217;t care.&nbsp; And it didn&#8217;t work, because they didn&#8217;t get elected.&nbsp; I got elected.</p>



<p>But the price of gasoline still rose over 35 percent and, in some cases, at some periods, it was 100 percent and 125 percent during certain periods of time.</p>



<p>Under the Trump administration, we have implemented a very different plan.&nbsp; You probably heard of it.&nbsp; It&#8217;s called drill, baby, drill, and we&#8217;re doing a &#8212; (applause).</p>



<p>The world runs on low-cost energy, and energy-producing nations like us have nothing to apologize for.&nbsp; We have more energy than any other nation in the world, and we&#8217;re going to use it.&nbsp; And we&#8217;re going to use it on AI plants.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I was telling some of the people that came in that &#8212; you know, they&#8217;re very inter- &#8212; everybody&#8217;s talking about AI.&nbsp; I hope you&#8217;re right.&nbsp; You know, I don&#8217;t know.&nbsp; Who knows?&nbsp; (Laughter.)</p>



<p>But, Elon, are they right?&nbsp; Are they right in going all i- &#8212; they are all in for AI.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But the problem is, to do it, just in our country, you need twice the electricity just to open up and be the top of AI.&nbsp; You need twice the electricity that we have right now.&nbsp; In the entire country, if you take all of the electricity, you need more than twice.&nbsp; You need twice.&nbsp; You need double what we have right now just to fuel this new industry that&#8217;s growing.&nbsp; I was amazed when I heard that number.</p>



<p>And they all said, How can we do this?&nbsp; Because, you know, in China and various other places, you can probably get it with the shake of a hand, but in our country, you can&#8217;t.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But now you can, because we&#8217;ve declared &#8212; I&#8217;m declaring a national emergency in order to get fast approvals.&nbsp; And we&#8217;re going to have &#8212; if you build a plant, you&#8217;re able to build an electric-generating facility right next to your plant, so you&#8217;ll be making your own.&nbsp; You won&#8217;t have to count on utilities.&nbsp; You won&#8217;t have to count on an old grid that could fail, could get hit by something &#8212; bad things or good things &#8212; but you&#8217;re not going to have to &#8212; you&#8217;re not going to have to worry about grids.&nbsp; You&#8217;re not going to have &#8212; youll build your plant, and you&#8217;ll build your &#8212; your &#8212; essentially, you become a utility, in a way. &nbsp;You build your own electricity.&nbsp; If you want to build extra and put it out and get paid for that, you&#8217;re going to be able to do that.&nbsp; You could put it back into the grid, but you&#8217;re going to be able to build with your plant a generating facility.</p>



<p>And we&#8217;re going to get you Lee Zeldin, head of the environment &#8212; head of Environmental &#8212; the Environmental group &#8212; various groups.&nbsp; And we&#8217;ve got them unified now, but we&#8217;re going to get you very fast approvals, and they&#8217;ll be approved so fast your head will spin.&nbsp; And we&#8217;re going to get that whole industry started, and we&#8217;re going to be the head of it.&nbsp; We&#8217;re leading right now.&nbsp; We have the greatest brain power.&nbsp; We&#8217;re leading right now, and I expect that we&#8217;re going to be leading by a lot.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we&#8217;re going to get you the energy very, very quickly.&nbsp; That would be the one thing that everybody was concerned, How do we have that much electricity when Los Angeles has blackouts and brownouts right now, and there&#8217;s a lack of electricity?&nbsp; But we&#8217;re going to get it at levels never seen before.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I ended the ridiculous Green New Scam, halting tens of billions of dollars of wasteful deficit spending.&nbsp; And I withdrew the United States from the unfair, one-sided Paris Climate Accord.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And I ended Joe Biden&#8217;s insane electric vehicle mandate, because it was just insane.&nbsp; I repealed the last &#8212; and, by the way, if you want to buy an electric car, that&#8217;s great.&nbsp; If you want to buy a gasoline-driven car or a hybrid, it&#8217;s great.&nbsp; Whatever the &#8212; whatever the thing happens to be.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I heard hydrogen is hot.&nbsp; The problem is, when it&#8217;s not, you&#8217;re in deep trouble.&nbsp; Because when that sucker blows up, they don&#8217;t find the body.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; So, that&#8217;s one that I said, You know what?&nbsp; Let&#8217;s take a pass on that one.&nbsp; They said it&#8217;s good, but when it&#8217;s bad, it&#8217;s really bad.&nbsp; You find the bodies on trees &#8212; on the side of a tree.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; I said, I think we&#8217;ll pass on that one.&nbsp; Right?&nbsp; We&#8217;re not going to want that one.&nbsp; But you never know.&nbsp; Maybe someday it&#8217;ll be good.&nbsp; But it doesn&#8217;t sound like it&#8217;s off to a good start.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I repealed the last administration&#8217;s very destructive natural gas export ban, and, last week, we approved our first new liquefied natural gas export license, and we have literally hundreds of people that want to export.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I recently met with the Japanese prime minister, Ishiba, to discuss large increases in American oil and gas exports.&nbsp; They want it so badly.&nbsp; They said, We went to the Biden administration, and they wouldn&#8217;t sell it.&nbsp; They wouldn&#8217;t sell it.&nbsp; Nobody knows why.&nbsp; Biden didn&#8217;t know why either.&nbsp; They asked him.&nbsp; I don&#8217;t know.&nbsp; (Laughter.)&nbsp; He wanted &#8212; they did?&nbsp; Oh, I didn&#8217;t know that.&nbsp;</p>



<p>But we&#8217;re going to sell it.&nbsp; And the new project in Alaska is going to feed all of Asia.&nbsp; We&#8217;re going to take care of all of Asia.&nbsp; We have so much oil and gas, like very few people &#8212; like very few countries have &#8212; like, really, actually, no country has.&nbsp;</p>



<p>I also met with Prime Minister Modi of India, who wants to greatly expand India&#8217;s purchase of American energy.&nbsp;</p>



<p>And my administration has also launched the most aggressive deregulation program of any nation in history.&nbsp; Under my executive order, for every 1 new regulation added, 10 old regulations have to be eliminated.&nbsp; (Applause.)</p>



<p>And, you know, in our first term, which was actually an incredible success &#8212; we had the greatest economy in history until COVID, and even after that, we did great.&nbsp; The stock market was higher.&nbsp; If you think of it, it was higher after the fact &#8212; after we went through that whole thing, it was higher than it was just prior to COVID coming in, which is a pretty amazing thing.&nbsp;</p>
